div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : A drawing-room in O ’ FARRELL ’ S house in John Street . It is very prettily but not extravagantly furnished . The O ’ FARRELLS are a young married couple of modest income .
It is between six and seven in the evening .
PEYTON , a neat parlour-maid , opens the door and shows in MR. DAVENPORT BARLOW .

BARLOW is a short , self-important person of middle age . He is very bald , red in the face , and wears a small , neatly curled moustache ; he is dressed in the height of fashion . His manner is fussy and pompous . He comes forward as though he expected to find some one in the room . Seeing that it is empty , he stops and looks at PEYTON . He cannot make out why there is no one to receive him .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: In a tone of surprise .Is Mrs. O ’ Farrell not here ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: H ’ m .... Will you let her know I ’ ve come ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. O ’ Farrell is not at home , sir .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Not at home ?... But ....

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , would you kindly sit down and make yourself comfortable ? And I was to give you the Morning Post .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Pompously .I can ’ t imagine why Mrs. O ’ Farrell should think I haven ’ t read the Morning Post at six o ’ clock in the evening .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Imperturbably .And Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , will you have a whisky and soda , sir ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But when is Mrs. O ’ Farrell coming in ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: I don ’ t know at all , sir .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But she telegraphed to me this afternoon , asking me to come and see her at once .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Yes , sir ; I took the telegram to the post office myself .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It seems very extraordinary that she should have gone out . The matter was of considerable importance .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Politely .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Very well , I ’ ll sit down and wait . But I can ’ t stay long . I ’ m dining at ... no matter .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: PEYTON goes out . BARLOW goes to a looking-glass , takes a little brush out of his pocket , and brushes his moustache . PEYTON comes in again with a small tray on which are a decanter , a syphon , and a glass .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Oh , thank you . Did you say you had the Morning Post ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: She hands it to him .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Ah , thank you .

div.stage: PEYTON goes out . BARLOW helps himself to a whisky and soda , turns to the fashionable intelligence in the paper , and begins to read it with a little smile of self-satisfaction .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Half to himself .The Duchess of St. Erth returned to Wales yesterday . The Marchioness of Mereston has arrived at 89 Grosvenor Square . The Marchioness of Serlo and Lady Eleanor King leave for Paris this morning .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in , followed by MRS. GOLIGHTLY . MRS. GOLIGHTLY is an extremely stout , good-natured lady of middle age . She is very active , but short of breath . She gives one a continual impression of having just run up a steep hill . She is DAVENPORT BARLOW ’ S sister .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. Golightly .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Isabel !

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Are you here , Davenport ? Where ’ s Penelope ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: As if it were the most extraordinary thing in the world .She ’ s out !

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Astonished .Out ?

div.stage: She turns to PEYTON with a look of inquiry .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , would you kindly sit down and make yourself comfortable , ma ’ am ? And I was to bring you the Church Times .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But ....

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Calmly .And Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , will you have a strong cup of tea , ma ’ am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I ’ m surprised that Mrs. O ’ Farrell should have gone out , because she expected me .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Handing MRS. GOLIGHTLY a paper .Yes , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Taking it .What is this ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: The Church Times , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a look of exasperation at BARLOW .Oh , thank you .... I think I will have a cup of tea , please .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Very good , ma ’ am .

div.stage: Exit .

lg.l: I wonder why on earth Penelope should insist on my reading the Church
Times .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I ’ ve just had a telegram from her .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: So have I , asking me to come at once .With a ray of light .Perhaps we shall find some explanation in the Church Times .

lg.l: Nonsense . What can the Church Times have to do with the Archduchess
Anastasia ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear Davenport , what are you talking about ?

div.stage: PEYTON enters to announce PROFESSOR GOLIGHTLY and immediately afterwards goes out . GOLIGHTLY is a tall , spare man with grey hair , well groomed and alert . He is neatly dressed , quite tidy , and might just as well be a lawyer or a doctor as a professor of mathematics . He is clean-shaven .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Professor Golightly .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Hulloa , Davenport !To his wife .My dear , you ’ re the last person I expected to find here . I thought there was a meeting of the Missionary Society at the Albert Hall .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in with a tray on which are tea-things , a glass of barley-water , and a copy of the “ Athenæum .”

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Oh , thank you .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: To GOLIGHTLY .Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , will you have a glass of barley-water , sir ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Barley-water !

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: And I was to bring you the Athenæum . We couldn ’ t get this week ’ s , sir , but this is last week ’ s , and Mrs. O ’ Farrell hopes it will do as well .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a faint smile .It ’ s very kind of you to have taken so much trouble .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Thank you , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What on earth does Penelope want me to do with last week ’ s Athenæum and a glass of barley-water ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Well , presumably she wants you to drink the one and to read the other .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: To his wife .My dear , I think it ’ s very hard that you should have brought up our only child on the idea that my favourite form of refreshment is barley-water .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It looks as if Penelope expected you , too .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I ’ ve just had a wire from her .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Have you ? I wonder why on earth she wired to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: It ’ s so extraordinary that she shouldn ’ t be here . It makes me feel very nervous .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Well , frankly , I couldn ’ t make head or tail of it , so I jumped into a motor cab and came round from the club at once .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in , followed by BEADSWORTH . He is a middle-aged solicitor , with a benign manner .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mr. Beadsworth .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Well , I ’ m hanged .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear Charles , I wish you wouldn ’ t be slangy . It ’ s gone out in our set .

lg.l: I ’ ve just had a telegram from
Penelope asking me to come at once .
Will you let
Mrs. O ’ Farrell know I ’ m here ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: She ’ s out .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. O ’ Farrell said , would you make yourself comfortable , sir , and we ’ ve got the Law Times if you ’ d like to read it , and will you have a glass of port , sir ?

div.stage: BEADSWORTH looks round at the others in bewilderment .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: By all means have a glass of port , and I ’ ll swop it for my barley-water .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: To PEYTON .Thank you .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Handing him the paper .Very good , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: What does she want me to do with the Law Times ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I asked the same question when Peyton handed me last week ’ s Athenæum , and Davenport , with the perspicacity that distinguishes him , answered : read it .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Can you tell me what Penelope wants ? Her telegram suggested that she wished to see me not as an old friend , but in my official capacity as the family solicitor .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I haven ’ t an idea . I thought her telegram most mysterious .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I wish she ’ d come in . I ’ m beginning to be dreadfully uneasy .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Rather pompously .I think I can put your minds at rest . I am in a position to explain the whole matter to you . The telegram she sent me makes it perfectly clear . I daresay you know that the Archduchess Anastasia is a patient of Dickie ’ s . And a very nice patient for him to have . I ’ ve never met her , though I happen to know several members of her family , and she ’ s a very cultivated , pleasant woman . I ’ ve always said to Dickie that that is the sort of practice he ought to get . The middle classes do a doctor no good .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear Davenport , do go on with your story .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Well , it appears that the Archduchess Anastasia has signified her desire to know Penelope . Very charming and graceful action on her part , and just like her . Of course she ’ s extremely grateful to Dickie for all he ’ s done . He ’ s worked a miraculous cure , and I daresay she ’ s heard that Penelope is my niece . It ’ s a maxim you can always go on : royalty knows everything . And the long and the short of it is that she ’ s coming to lunch here . Of course Penelope knows nothing about these matters , and in a state of great excitement she ’ s sent for me . It ’ s the best thing she could do . I can tell her everything . I ’ ve lived in that set all my life . It ’ s nothing to be particularly proud about — mere accident of birth — I happen to be a gentleman . A certain family . Well , there it is , you see .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But do you mean to say that Penelope wired all that to you ? It must have cost her a perfect fortune .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: She put it a little more briefly , of course , but that was the gist of it .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I can ’ t imagine why she should send for me because a royalty is coming to luncheon with her . It was very inconvenient to get away . I had a dozen people waiting to see me , and I was obliged to slip out by the back door in order to avoid them .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But what are the exact words of the wire she sent you , Davenport ?

lg.l: You can see it if you like .
lg.stage: Taking it from his pocket and reading .
lg.l: “ Come at once . Archduchess Anastasia . Penelope .”

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But d ’ you mean to say that you made up all that story out of those three words ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Penelope knew I had a certain amount of intelligence . She didn ’ t want to waste her money , so she just put what was essential , and left me to gather the rest .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But my telegram says nothing about the Archduchess Anastasia .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: What did Penelope say to you ?

lg.l: “ Come at once ! Grave scandal ! Central
African Mission . Penelope .”

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But that ’ s absurd . You know how stupid the Post Office is . They must have made a mistake . I know that the Pomeranian Royal Family is very odd , but there are limits , and I can ’ t imagine the Archduchess Anastasia being mixed up in a scandal with a Central African missionary .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Well , my wire merely said : “ Come at once ; six and eightpence . Penelope .”

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Six and eightpence ! Why six and eightpence ?

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I don ’ t know . That is why I lost no time in coming .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a twinkle .My impression is that the Archduchess Anastasia , instead of paying Dickie ’ s bill for miraculously curing her , has eloped with a missionary , and Penelope , by aid of the lawwith a gesture towards BEADSWORTH, wants to recover the money .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It ’ s nonsense ! You ’ re so unpractical , Charles .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: To her husband .But you had a telegram too , dear .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: “ Come at once . Decimal 7035 . Penelope .”

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: How very odd .

div.stage: The door is softly opened and PENELOPE slips in ; for a moment the others do not see her , and she stands smiling at them . GOLIGHTLY catches sight of her . All the others turn .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Penelope .

sp.speaker: THE OTHERS
sp.p: Penelope .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Coming forward and kissing MRS. GOLIGHTLY .Good evening , mamma !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Eagerly .Well ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , papa .She puts her face up for him to kiss .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Anxiously .Now , Penelope .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Beadsworth , how nice of you to come .She shakes hands with him .Kiss me , Uncle Davenport .She calmly puts up her face . With some irritation he kisses her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Thank you .... Was your whisky and soda quite right ?Looking round .And the port ? Father , you haven ’ t touched the barley-water . You ungrateful old thing !

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Exasperated .My dear , for goodness ’ sake explain .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Where have you been all this time ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I — I ’ ve been sitting in the consulting-room .With a roguish smile .I watched you all come in .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Rather injured .Peyton said you were out .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Really , Penelope , I think your behaviour is outrageous .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You see , I thought if I saw you one after the other as you came in , I should have to make four scenes instead of one . It would have been very exhausting and not nearly so effective .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Are you going to make a scene ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With the greatest satisfaction .I ’ m going to make a dreadful scene in a minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Now , my dear , before you go any further , for goodness ’ sake tell us what you meant by your telegrams .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , you see , I wanted you all to come immediately , and I thought the best thing was to trail your ruling passions under your noses .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Do you understand what she means , Charles ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear mother , it ’ s the simplest thing in the world . You spend your life in converting the heathen — from a distance — and I knew if I mentioned the Central African Mission you ’ d fly here on the wings of the wind .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: In point of fact I came in an omnibus . But do you mean to tell me that there has been no scandal in connection with the Central African Mission ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling .I ’ m dreadfully sorry to disappoint you , mother .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: And what in heaven ’ s name made you wire decimal 7035 to me ?

lg.l: Oh , that ’ s our telephone number , and I just put decimal instead of
Gerrard .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I thought the figures were strangely familiar .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And there you are , you see .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Chuckling .I think it ’ s a capital idea . And she just flung the words six and eightpence at you , Beadsworth , and knew she ’ d fetch the lawyer .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To BEADSWORTH .You ’ re not cross with me , are you ?

div.stage: He shakes his head , smiling .

lg.l: And now , my dear , that you ’ ve disposed of them , tell me all about the
Archduchess Anastasia .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Looking at him blankly .The Archduchess Anastasia ? But I invented her .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: What d ’ you mean , you invented her ? I know her well , I ’ ve known her for years . I know her whole family .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Rather embarrassed , but trying not to laugh .Well , you see — I wanted you to come , too . And ....

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I don ’ t understand what you mean at all , Penelope . You mention one of my most intimate friends , and then you tell me you invented her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m awfully sorry . I really didn ’ t know there was such a person , and I thought I ’ d made her up out of my own head ....With a chuckle .I think it was rather clever of me to hit upon some one you know so well .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you should think the mere mention of the Archduchess ’ s name would make me come here .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , you see , I know that you go out a great deal , and you know such crowds of people . I felt quite sure that if there were an Archduchess Anastasia you ’ d know her , andwith a wave of the handwell , there it is you see .

div.stage: BARLOW fumes silently , but does not answer .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Now , Penelope , tell us what you really do want .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: In matter-of-fact tones .I want to divorce Dickie .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear child .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good gracious !

div.stage: These three speeches are said simultaneously .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ruefully .I intended to make such a scene , and now you ’ ve made me blurt it all out in three words .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But I don ’ t understand .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll say it again , shall I ? I want to divorce Dickie .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: You don ’ t really mean it , do you ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Indignantly .Of course I mean it . I ’ m never going to speak to him again . That ’ s to say , I shall have a scene with him first . I ’ m quite determined to have a scene with somebody .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: And where is Dickie now ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: He ’ s on his way home with the usual story .With a sudden break in her voice .Oh , if you only knew how utterably miserable I am .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My darling , is it really serious ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Desperately .Oh , what can I do to make you all understand ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: The best way would be to begin at the beginning , and tell us all about it coherently .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Pompously .My dear Charles , this is not the kind of matter in which you can be of any use . You ’ re a mathematician , and you ’ re not expected to know anything about practical affairs .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Faintly ironic .I apologise profusely .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: To PENELOPE , to ask her to speak .Darling ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , the first thing is that I simply dote upon Dickie . I ’ ve never loved any one else , and I never shall .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: That ’ s a very satisfactory confession after four years of matrimony .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Five years , three months , and two days . And every day I ’ ve loved Dickie more .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I ’ ve never seen a more devoted couple .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: We ’ ve never had a quarrel . We ’ ve never even been cross with one another . It ’ s been a honeymoon that ’ s never come to an end .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And now I ’ ve discovered that he ’ s been lying to me for the last month . He ’ s been coming home dreadfully late , and when I ’ ve asked him where he ’ s been , he ’ s said that he had to see a patient who was very ill — such an interesting case — and it worried him so much that he was obliged to go to his club and have a rubber to settle his nerves . And the interesting case and the rubber of bridge are Ada Fergusson .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Pompously .But who is Ada Fergusson ? I ’ ve never heard of her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ada Fergusson ’ s a great friend of mine . And I hate her . I always knew she was a cat . For the last four weeks Dickie ’ s been spending every afternoon with her from four till seven .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Raising his eyebrows .But do you always ask your husband where he ’ s been when he comes in ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Impatiently .My dear papa , what has that got to do with it ? We all know that you ’ re an old dear , and the greatest mathematician in the world , but you know nothing about life at all .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I apologise again .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Give him a sheet of paper and a pencil , Penelope , and he ’ ll amuse himself by doing sums while we talk the matter out .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Pushing writing materials over to him .There you are , papa .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: But how did you find out ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , what does it matter how I found out ! I ’ ve got all sorts of proofs .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You could knock me down with a feather .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a smile .My dear !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I am not in the least surprised .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Uncle Davenport !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I have expected it all along . You will remember , Isabel , that I was against the marriage from the beginning . I said , one doesn ’ t marry a doctor . One sometimes meets them in society when they ’ ve had their angles rubbed off a little and perhaps have been knighted , but one never meets their wives . We suppose they do marry , but they don ’ t marry any one we know . I may be old-fashioned , but I stick to my opinion that there are only three possible professions for a gentleman , the law , the army , and the church .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear Uncle Davenport , you ’ re talking nonsense .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Huffily .You ask me for my opinion , and I give it you . I regret that you should think it nonsense .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: And what are you proposing to do now ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With great determination .I ’ m never going to live with Dickie again . As soon as I ’ ve seen him I shall leave this house for ever .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: You ’ re proposing to have a few words with him ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Several . I ’ m going to tell him that I despise him , and that I hate him ; I ’ m going to throw my wedding ring in his face , and then I shall sweep out of the room .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Have you really made up your mind that you won ’ t forgive him ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Nothing would induce me ever to speak to him again if it weren ’ t that I want to tell him exactly what I think of him .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Besides , you ’ ve got your family to think of . Of course you must leave him . You see , that is what I say , you ’ re not safe with people of no birth . I look upon all this as a blessing in disguise .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Do you wish to bring an action for judicial separation ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear Mr. Beadsworth , what are you talking about ! I ’ m going to divorce him . I ’ m going to make an awful scandal .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Well , I suppose we could arrange that at a pinch with the help of the newspapers . Has he ever been cruel to you ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good heavens , no ! That ’ s what makes me so angry . The last month he ’ s been more perfectly charming and delightful than ever . Oh , I wish I could do something really unpleasant to Ada Fergusson . Something with boiling oil in it .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I am shocked , frankly shocked . I would never have thought that Dickie could be so wicked .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Family life in England is going to the dogs . That is the long and short of it .

div.stage: Suddenly PENELOPE catches sight of what GOLIGHTLY has been diligently writing . She gives the paper a startled look and then turns round .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Mother , a dreadful thing has happened . Papa has suddenly become a drivelling lunatic .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , what are you saying ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: He ’ s been adding two and two together all over that piece of paper , and he makes it five every time .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Charles !

div.stage: PENELOPE hands the sheet to BARLOW .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Look .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Two and two are five . Two and two are five .

div.stage: He passes it on to BEADSWORTH .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Two and two are five . Two and two are five .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I knew this would happen . I ’ ve been expecting it for years .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Charles , pull yourself together .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Papa , you don ’ t really think that two and two are five ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: On the contrary , I ’ m convinced that two and two are four .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then why on earth have you made it five ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Do you know why you buy Pears ’ soap ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I expect you ’ ve been working too hard , father dear . Why don ’ t you go and lie down for half an hour ? And when Dickie comes in he ’ ll give you a tonic .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You buy Pears ’ soap because you ’ re told on fifty thousand hoardings that it ’ s matchless for the complexion .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That ’ s not funny , papa , that ’ s silly .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You ’ ve only got to say a thing often enough , and all the world will believe it . And when the world believes it , it ’ s very hard to say if it ’ s true or not .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What has that got to do with two and two ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I thought if I wrote “ two and two are five ” often enough I might come to think it true .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But if you wrote it a million times it wouldn ’ t be any truer .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: That is the conclusion I ’ m regretfully forced to .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: The whole of life is merely a matter of adding two and two together and getting the right answer .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear Charles , if you ’ re going to discuss life I think there ’ s no need for me to stay . I ’ ve told you for twenty years that you ’ re a scholar and a recluse . I have lived in the world , and I ’ m a practical man . If Penelope wants to consult me , I am at her service ; if not ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Hold your tongue , Uncle Davenport .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Really , Penelope .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: During the last five years I ’ ve seen you adding two and two together and making them about seventy-nine .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I don ’ t know what you ’ re talking about , Charles . Dickie ’ s behaviour is abominable , and there are no excuses for him . It ’ s a mere matter of common morality .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , I have no objection to you talking common morality if you ’ ll let me talk common sense .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear Charles , they ’ re the same thing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: If you think you can make me forgive Dickie by telling me that you were a wicked old thing yourself in your youth , I may as well tell you at once that it won ’ t wash .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Outraged .What are you talking about , my dear ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , I ’ ve noticed that when a woman discovers that her husband has been unfaithful , her male relations invariably try to console her by telling her how shockingly they ’ ve treated their own wives .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , I was going to confess nothing of the sort . I never confess .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course , if it were the other way about , and mamma had kicked over the traces a little ....

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Darling , can you see me performing an acrobatic feat of that character ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Go on , papa .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I think you ’ ve treated Dickie shamefully .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Astounded .I ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: If your mother had behaved to me as you ’ ve behaved to Dickie , I should certainly have taken to drink .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But I ’ ve been a perfect angel . I ’ ve simply worshipped the ground he walked on . I ’ ve loved him as no man was ever loved before .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: No man could stand it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Papa , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , you ’ ve loved him morning , noon , and night . You ’ ve loved him when he talked , and you ’ ve loved him when he was silent . You ’ ve loved him walking , you ’ ve loved him eating , you ’ ve loved him sleeping . He ’ s never been able to escape from your love .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But I couldn ’ t help it .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You need not have shown it .

lg.l: And do you mean to say that justifies him in philandering with Ada
Fergusson ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: It excuses him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What beasts men must be !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: No ; but strange as it may seem to you , they ’ re human beings . When you were a child you doted on strawberry ices .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I dote on them still .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Would you like to eat strawberry ice for breakfast , lunch , tea , and dinner every day for a month ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good heavens ! the thought fills me with horror .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Poor Dickie has lived on strawberry ice for five years . It ’ s been his only means of sustenance .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With consternation .Oh !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You ’ ve never let him go out without coming into the hall to put on his hat and kiss him good-bye ; he ’ s never come into the house without you running down to help him off with his coat and kiss him welcome . When he sat down after breakfast in the morning to read his paper and smoke his pipe , I ’ ve seen you sit down on the arm of his chair and put your arm round his neck .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Outraged .Penelope !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do you think it was very awful ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear child !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To BEADSWORTH .Did Mrs. Beadsworth never sit on the arm of your chair when you were smoking your pipe ?

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I must confess I ’ m thankful my wife occupied those moments in attending to her household duties .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You are a lot of horrid old things . I ask you to come here to sympathise with me , and you ’ re perfectly brutal to me .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear Penelope , there are limits .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , I don ’ t care ; I ’ m going to divorce him .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Let ’ s do another little simple addition , shall we ? Perhaps two and two will make four a second time .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I don ’ t know that I much like being a mathematician ’ s daughter .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Don ’ t you think , instead of divorcing your husband , it would be better to win back his affection ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I don ’ t want his affection .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Smiling .Are you sure you wouldn ’ t if you could get it ?

div.stage: PENELOPE looks at her father for a moment , then goes up to him quickly .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With tears in her voice .Papa , d ’ you think I ever could win back his love ? You say I ’ ve lost it through my own fault . Oh , I don ’ t know what to do without him . I ’ ve been so wretched since I knew . I ’ ve tried to put a cheerful face on it , but if you knew what I feel in my heart .... Oh , the brutes , why didn ’ t they hide it from me ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear Penelope , I expected you to have more spirit . He ’ s a person of no family . I should have thought you were well rid of him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Uncle Davenport , if you say a word against him , I will immediately have an attack of hysterics .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: What you expect your father to be able to tell you I can ’ t imagine .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Smiling .Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings , Davenport ....

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have thought one could describe you as either . But , in any case , I can stay no longer .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , don ’ t go yet , Uncle Davenport .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It appears that my advice is not wanted , and I promised to look in on dear Lady Hollington before dinner .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do telephone to her that you can ’ t come . You ’ ll find a telephone in my sitting-room .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .I ’ m too indulgent . People don ’ t rate me at my proper value .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Papa , say you ’ ll get Dickie back for me . I want him . I want him .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , it ’ s very simple . It merely requires a great deal of tact , a great deal of courage , and a great deal of self-control .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ironically .Nothing else ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: A good deal . You must never let yourself out of hand ; you must keep guard on your tongue and your eyes and your smiles — and your temper .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I think you said it was very simple .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Is Ada Fergusson pretty ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , she ’ s perfectly hideous .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Is she ? That makes it more serious .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: If a man falls in love with a pretty woman , he falls out of it . But if he falls in love with a plain one , he ’ ll be in love with her all his life .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You take a load off my mind . Ada Fergusson ’ s extremely attractive .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Then you ’ ll get him back .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Tell me exactly what to do , and I ’ ll do it .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Give him his head .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: It means a good deal . When he comes in , don ’ t make a scene , but be charming to him . For once , don ’ t ask him where he ’ s been . When he leaves you , don ’ t ask him where he ’ s going , nor at what time he ’ ll be back . Don ’ t let him know that you have the least suspicion that anything has happened . On the contrary , take every opportunity of throwing him into Ada Fergusson ’ s society .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Charles , you ’ re asking Penelope to connive at immorality .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: When every difficulty disappears , Dickie will find half the savour of the intrigue gone . Half your battle is won . Leave the rest to time and Ada Fergusson . Let Ada Fergusson sit on the arm of his chair when he wants to read his paper . Let him account to Ada Fergusson for all his movements . Under such circumstances a woman is always on tenterhooks , and consequently she ’ s always exacting . Whenever there ’ s a pause in the conversation , Ada Fergusson will say , Do you care for me as much as ever you did ? That speech is the rope around love ’ s throat . Whenever he wants to go away , Ada Fergusson will implore him to stay five minutes longer . Those five minutes that a man stays against his will are the nails in love ’ s coffin . Each time he leaves her Ada Fergusson will say , At what time will you be back ? That question is the earth shovelled into love ’ s grave .

div.stage: All this while PENELOPE has been staring at GOLIGHTLY with astonishment .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Where did you learn all this , father ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a deprecating shrug .It ’ s a mere matter of adding two and two together , my darling .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I had no idea that mathematics were so interesting — nor so immoral .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What do you think of it ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But if Dickie falls out of love with Ada Fergusson there ’ s no reason why he should fall in love again with me .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You must make him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wish I knew how .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: It only requires a little more tact , a little more courage , and a little more self-control .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But if I acquire so many virtues I shan ’ t be a woman , but a monster , and how can he love me then ?

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: From the window .There ’ s a car stopping at the door .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Listen .... I can hear a key being turned . It must be Dickie .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Hesitating .What do you think , mamma ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , I highly disapprove of your father ’ s idea , and I can ’ t imagine how it ever came into his head , but I ’ m bound to say I think there ’ s some sense in it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Making up her mind .I ’ ll try . Remember , no one knows anything that has happened . You ’ ll back me up , mamma , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You ’ re not going to ask me to tell a pack of lies , darling ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Only white ones , mother . If there ’ s a whopper to tell , I ’ ll tell it myself .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: But what about Barlow ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: He ’ s a man of the world . He ’ s sure to put his foot in it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll settle him .

div.stage: BARLOW comes in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I could not get on to her . I don ’ t know what ’ s the matter with those telephone girls . Hussies !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Uncle Davenport , I find I ’ ve been entirely mistaken about Dickie . He ’ s not to blame in any way .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good gracious me ! And Ada Fergusson ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Is , I have no doubt , no worse than anybody else .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: This is a surprise . How on earth have you come to this conclusion ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: By adding two and two together .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Upon my word ! I must say , it annoys me that I should have been forced to break an important engagement for no reason . I should have thought ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Interrupting .Uncle Davenport , it ’ s quite bad enough that I should be done out of a scene , but if you ’ re going to make one it ’ s more than I can stand .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Well , as I can ’ t be of any more use to you , I think I ’ ll get back to the bosom of my family .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course , I look upon this as a professional visit .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: Oh , nonsense !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I couldn ’ t dream of accepting your services for nothing . You must really let me know what I owe you .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I really don ’ t know what to say .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie charges a guinea when he goes to see anybody .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: You only mentioned six and eightpence in your telegram .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Very well , I ’ ll owe you that . It would really make me feel more comfortable .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: You ’ re not going to hand it over in hard cash ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wasn ’ t thinking of paying you . But I ’ d like to think I owed it you . You see , then , I shan ’ t feel under any obligation .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: In that case I surrender . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good-bye , Beadsworth . You must come and dine with me at the club one of these days .

sp.speaker: BEADSWORTH
sp.p: I should like to . Good-bye .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Very nice fellow . Quite a gentleman . No one would think he was a solicitor . I shall ask him to dinner with one or two people who don ’ t matter .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: There ’ s Dickie . D ’ you hear him whistling ? He ’ s evidently in the best of spirits .

div.stage: DICKIE comes in . He is a good-looking , well-dressed , professional man of five-and-thirty . He has boisterous spirits and high good humour . He is seldom put out of countenance . He has a charm of manner which explains PENELOPE ’ S infatuation .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hulloa ! I couldn ’ t make out what had become of you , Pen .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You generally come down to meet me when I get in .

div.stage: PENELOPE gives a slight start and conceals a smile .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My sainted mother is here .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Gaily .That ’ s no reason why you should neglect a devoted husband .Shaking hands with MRS. GOLIGHTLY .How is your sainted mother ? Hulloa , Uncle Davenport , what price duchesses to-day ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I don ’ t know what you mean .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Looking round at the decanters and glasses with which the room is scattered .I say , you ’ ve been doing yourselves rather proud , haven ’ t you ? Who ’ s been drinking port ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Nobody . It ’ s an empty glass .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s how providence behaves to me . Deliberately puts temptation in my way . It ’ s simply poison . Gout in my family , you know . My ancestors have lived on colchicum for a hundred years . I feel a tingling in my toes at the mere sight of a bottle of port . And yet I drink it .

div.stage: He fills himself a glass and sips it with great content .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It ’ s a great mistake , of course , to think that gout is a mark of good family . The porter of my club is a martyr to it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Perhaps he ’ s the illegitimate son of an earl . You should ask him if he has a strawberry mark on his left shoulder . What ’ s the matter , Pen ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Astonished .With me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I thought you seemed a bit under the weather .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know . You ’ re not quite up to your usual form , are you ? You ’ ve not asked me what I ’ ve been doing to-day . As a rule you ’ re so interested in my movements .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a glance at her father .I thought you ’ d tell me if you wanted to .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , I do think that ’ s a bit thick . I go slaving my very soul out to provide you with a motor and nice frocks and things , and you don ’ t take the smallest interest in what I do .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling .Well , what have you been doing this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a sigh of relief .Oh , I ’ ve had the very deuce of a day . I ’ ve got a very interesting case on just now . Taking up a lot of my time . Of course , it worries me rather , but I suppose all these things come in the day ’ s march . Well , I spent the best part of an hour there .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: An hour ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , we had a consultation , you know .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But you had a consultation yesterday .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yesterday ? Yes , she ’ s a fussy old thing . She ’ s always wanting consultations .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That ’ s jolly , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t think it is . It looks as if she hadn ’ t really confidence in me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: On the other hand , you can charge double , can ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , of course , it has that advantage .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ve been hankering after an ermine stole for a long time . I shall buy it now .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: His face falling .Oh , but I haven ’ t been paid yet .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: They ’ ll be only too glad to wait . And it ’ s such a bargain .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: To change the conversation .Well , after my consultation I was so fagged that I had to go into the club to have a rubber of Bridge .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: By the way , what is the name of your patient ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: The name of my patient ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I was telling papa that you ’ d got a new patient who was bringing in pots of money . I couldn ’ t remember her name .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Embarrassed .Oh — er , Mrs. Mac ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Mrs. Mac what ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Mrs. Macnothing .

lg.l: How d ’ you mean , Mrs. Macnothing ? I ’ ve never heard of a family called
Macnothing .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No , of course , her name isn ’ t Macnothing .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But you distinctly said it was Mrs. Macnothing .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Now , my dear Pen , did I say anything about Macnothing ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , what is her name then ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ve been telling you for the last ten minutes . Her name ’ s Mrs. Mack .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Why on earth didn ’ t you say so at once ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: How did you find such a profitable patient ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , it was a great piece of luck . She heard about me from that little friend of yours , Pen . What is her name ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You seem to have a very bad memory for names , Dickie . You should make a knot in your handkerchief .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s a friend of Pen ’ s .Pretending to try and remember .Her husband ’ s in the navy , stationed at Malta , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ada Fergusson .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s it , of course . Mrs. Fergusson .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: One of the Fergussons of Kingarth , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know at all . Quite a nice little thing , I thought . I must confess that she didn ’ t interest me very much .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in to announce MRS. FERGUSSON . MRS. FERGUSSON is a handsome , showy woman of about thirty .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. Fergusson .

div.stage: DICKIE is filled with consternation . PEYTON goes out . There is a very brief moment of embarrassment , but PENELOPE quickly recovers herself and goes up to the visitor effusively .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Is it a preposterous hour to pay a call ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course not . I ’ m always delighted to see you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ ve been shopping the whole afternoon , and it suddenly occurred to me that I hadn ’ t seen you for ages .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do you know my sainted mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: This is my noble father , and this is my uncle .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

div.stage: He is evidently much struck by MRS. FERGUSSON .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Turning blandly to DICKIE .You haven ’ t forgotten me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: We haven ’ t met for ages , have we ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Simply ages .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I passed you in Piccadilly the other day , and you cut me dead .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry , I ’ m so short-sighted .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie , you ’ re not at all short-sighted . How can you tell such fibs ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: With pompous gallantry .Dickie feels that only a physical impediment can excuse a man for not seeing a pretty woman .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , how very nice of you to say that .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Not at all , not at all .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wanted to thank you for getting Dickie such a splendid patient .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hastily , seeing her look of astonishment .I ’ ve just been telling my wife about Mrs. Mack .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Not in the least understanding .Oh , yes .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It was really awfully good of you to tell her to send for me . I ’ ve been to see her this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Understanding .Oh , yes . I like to do all I can for people . I hope you ’ ll find her a nice patient .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: She seems to require a lot of visits .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Yes , she was only telling me the other day how much she liked Dr. O ’ Farrell . I ’ m afraid she ’ s very ill , poor dear .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: To tell you the truth , I ’ m extremely worried about her .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It ’ s a great comfort to all her friends to know that Dr. O ’ Farrell is looking after her .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I ’ ve been wondering if she ’ s one of the Staffordshire Macks or one of the Somersetshire Macks .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know at all .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: How d ’ you mean you don ’ t know at all ? She must be one or the other .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t see that it matters either way .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What is she like ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t know . Like everybody else , I suppose .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Don ’ t be silly , Dickie . You must know if she ’ s fat or thin .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Looking at MRS. FERGUSSON .I should say fat , wouldn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Obese .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She has grey hair .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: All in little corkscrew curls .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Laughing .Yes . I wonder how she does them .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: She has very pretty blue eyes , hasn ’ t she ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , very pretty blue eyes .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What is her Christian name ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Er — I don ’ t know at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Promptly .Catherine .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Catherine Mack ? Mother , it ’ s your old friend Catherine Mack . What an extraordinary coincidence !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Catherine Mack . Why , of course , I remember her perfectly . Little grey corkscrew curls and very pretty blue eyes .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t she like mamma to go and see her ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid she can ’ t see any one just yet .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You must tell her how sorry we are to hear she ’ s so ill .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I ’ ll give her any message you like .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Rather stiffly , getting up .I think I ought to be going . Will you come , Charles ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Yes , my dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good-bye , mother , darling .

div.stage: They talk aside as MRS. GOLIGHTLY is helped on with her cloak . DICKIE is left practically alone with MRS. FERGUSSON .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: In an undertone .I say , what the dickens have you come here for now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You didn ’ t tell me when I should see you to-morrow .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Good heavens , you might have rung me up on the telephone .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , I never trust the telephone .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How do you mean you never trust the telephone ? Are you in the habit ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Dickie !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I beg your pardon , I didn ’ t mean that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Why on earth did you invent that cock-and-bull story about Mrs. Mack ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I didn ’ t . It invented itself . I was obliged to account for my movements .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say your wife asks you where you ’ ve been and where you ’ re going ? How like a woman .Innocently .By the way , what are you doing this evening ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With amusement .Oh , Penelope and I are dining at the Carlton grill room , and going to a music hall .

div.stage: BARLOW comes up to them .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good-bye , Mrs. Fergusson .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Effusively .Good-bye .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: To PENELOPE , as he shakes hands with her .Devilish fine woman .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Pretending to be outraged .Uncle Davenport !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good-bye , dear . Quite a lady .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: BARLOW and MRS. GOLIGHTLY go out .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: As he is following .Are you all right ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , leave it to me . I ’ m beginning to feel my feet .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a smile .I noticed it .

div.stage: GOLIGHTLY goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Charming man your uncle is , Penelope . So distinguished .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You ’ ve made a conquest of him . He told me you were a devilish fine woman .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Not really ? Men often tell me I ’ m a womanly woman .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I daresay it means the same thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: But I must fly too . I really had no idea it was so late .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Are you doing anything to-night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , no ! I live very quietly . There ’ s nothing that I enjoy more than an evening all by myself , with a book .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You used to be so fond of going out .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I know that my husband prefers me to remain at home . And when I think of him bravely serving his country in a foreign land I have no heart for gaiety .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What a charming nature you have .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: To DICKIE .My husband ’ s in a man-of-war . He ’ s stationed at Malta , you know . It ’ s so dreadful that my health forces me to remain in England .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wonder if you ’ d do me a great kindness .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: My dear , I ’ ll always do anything for an old friend .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: The fact is , I ’ ve had a perfectly fiendish headache the whole afternoon .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Triumphantly .I knew there was something the matter with you the moment I came in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: We ’ ve got a couple of stalls for a music hall to-night . It would be awfully kind of you if you ’ d go with Dickie instead of me .

div.stage: A look of intelligence passes between DICKIE and MRS. FERGUSSON .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie hates going out alone , and I simply can ’ t stir . You can have a jolly little dinner together at a restaurant , and you can go on afterwards .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Are you really sure you can ’ t go , Pen ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s absolutely out of the question .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Don ’ t you think Dr. O ’ Farrell ought to stay and look after you ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no ! It ’ ll do him good to go out . He ’ s been working so dreadfully hard . This afternoon he had a consultation that lasted nearly an hour .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: To DICKIE .Would you like me to come with you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I should love it , if it wouldn ’ t bore you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Then I shall be delighted .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Thanks so much . But it ’ s getting very late . I think you ought to start at once .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ re sure you don ’ t mind my leaving you , Penelope ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Positive .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , just wait a moment , and I ’ ll make you up a dose of something .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Hastily .Oh , no , I promise you I ’ m much better without medicine .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Nonsense . Of course I must give you something .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: That ’ s the advantage of having a doctor in the family .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Crossly .Yes , it ’ s a great advantage .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I do envy you , having your husband always at hand . When I think of mine bravely serving his country — and you know , every doctor I go to tells me it would be most dangerous for me to join him .

div.stage: DICKIE comes in with a little medicine glass , filled with a milky fluid .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Here it is .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , Dickie , I ’ d much rather not .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Don ’ t be silly , darling . This ’ ll pull you together like anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ m sure she ought to lie down .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , I think I ’ d rather stand up if you don ’ t mind .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How extraordinarily unreasonable you are ! Now lie down on this sofa .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course , if I absolutely must .

div.stage: She lies down on a sofa .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: We must make you comfortable before we go .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Let ’ s put all the cushions behind her . Is that nice ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , thank you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Poor little thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ m sure she ought to have something over her feet .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Let ’ s put this rug over her feet . There . Now take this medicine .... There ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , Dickie . I ’ ll take it after you ’ ve gone . I really will . I promise you I ’ ll take it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Why on earth can ’ t you take it now ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , I hate making faces before you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But I ’ ve often seen you make faces .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , at you . That ’ s quite a different thing .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Now , take it like a good girl .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: After you ’ ve gone .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With great determination .I ’ m not going to stir from this room till you ’ ve taken it .

lg.l: Give it me . Hold my nose , Dickie .
lg.stage: She swallows it and makes a face .
lg.l: Oh , I wish I ’ d never married you , Dickie .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ ll make you feel like one o ’ clock .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I don ’ t want to feel like one o ’ clock .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Good-bye . So sorry you ’ re feeling seedy .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Good-bye , darling .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I hope you ’ ll have an awfully good time .

div.stage: DICKIE and MRS. FERGUSSON go out . PENELOPE springs up , throws the cushions angrily aside , makes one or two quick steps towards the door as though to call them back , then stops .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , I won ’ t . I won ’ t .

div.stage: She comes slowly back , then sinks down and bursts into tears .
END OF THE FIRST ACT .

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : DR. O ’ FARRELL ’ S consulting-room . It is a comfortably furnished room , with engravings on the walls , photographs in silver frames , and flowers on the chimney-piece . There is a large desk on one side , with papers on it , books , and a reading-lamp . There is a revolving-chair for DICKIE to sit in , and a chair on the other side of the desk for the patient . On a side table are a microscope , a stand for test tubes , one or two medicine bottles , a row of large bottles containing chemicals , and an electric lamp . There is a sofa without arms for patients to lie upon , and there are two or three chairs besides . On the shelves are medical books . On a little table is a pile of “ Lancets .”

DICKIE is sitting at his desk , with his stethoscope still in his ears . A patient is standing up , buttoning up his braces . He puts on his waistcoat and coat as the conversation proceeds . He is a very timid little man , with a bald head and gold spectacles . He has an intensely nervous , apologetic manner .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ll just write you out a prescription , shall I ?

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s too good of you . I ’ m afraid I ’ m giving you so much trouble .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Not at all . Now what would you like me to give you ?

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Dreadfully embarrassed .Oh , whatever you like , please . It ’ s too good of you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You know , there ’ s not much the matter with you .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so sorry . I really , really ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I should have thought you ’ d be rather pleased .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Apologetically .Yes , of course , I ’ m very much pleased . I didn ’ t mean that . I ’ ve taken up so much of your time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s only out of the people who ’ ve got nothing the matter with them that I make a living . The people who are ill either get well or die , and that ’ s the end of them .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Yes , I see . I never thought of that . Beautiful day it is , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Won ’ t you sit down ?

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s too good of you . Thank you , thank you . I ’ m afraid I ’ m taking up so much of your time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I always make my patients sit on the other side of my desk since one of them suddenly saw a snake on me , and flung himself at my throat in order to save me from being bitten . He nearly throttled me in the process , and when I knelt on his chest , he said I was an ungrateful devil , and he wouldn ’ t interfere with the snakes next time they went for me .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Extremely agitated .Oh , but you don ’ t think there ’ s any danger of my flying at your throat , do you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a laugh .No , of course not .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: I drink nothing for my luncheon , and only claret and water for my dinner .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I suppose you wouldn ’ t think you ’ d had your money ’ s worth if I gave you no medicine ?

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s too good of you , but I think , for my wife ’ s sake , I ’ d like to take something .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , look here , I ’ ve given you some strychnine to buck you up , and some bismuth to quiet you down . Take it three times a day after meals .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , thank you so much . I ’ m sure it ’ s just what I want . And now — er . And now — er ....

div.stage: He gets up , overcome with embarrassment .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think there ’ s nothing more I can do for you .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: No , er — thank you very much . I — er — it ’ s so good of you to have taken so much trouble . Yes , er ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Understanding .Oh .... My fee is two guineas .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Infinitely relieved .Oh , thank you so much . That ’ s just what I wanted to ask you . Shall I write you a cheque ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: We always prefer to have it in hard cash , you know , in case it ’ s a bogus cheque .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , certainly . It ’ s too good of you . I thought you mightn ’ t like it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s extraordinary how nervous people are about giving a doctor money . If you only knew how jolly glad he is to get it .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Yes . Thank you very much .

div.stage: The patient takes two guineas out of his pocket and puts them nervously on the chimney-piece .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hang it all , man , not on the mantelpiece . There are limits .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon . I ’ m so sorry .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: We always like it put on the desk .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: I don ’ t often come and consult doctors .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I can see that . If you did you ’ d probably give me two pounds and say you hadn ’ t got two shillings on you , especially if you were a woman .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: You don ’ t say so . Really it never occurred to me .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Thank you . Well , good-bye .

sp.speaker: PATIENT
sp.p: Good-bye , and thank you so much . Beautiful day , isn ’ t it ? Good-bye .

div.stage: DICKIE leads him to the door and shows him out . At the door he sees GOLIGHTLY .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hulloa ! Come in , won ’ t you ?Calling upstairs .Pen , here ’ s your noble parent .

div.stage: GOLIGHTLY comes in .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I was just going up to see Pen .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Come and sit down here , and we ’ ll have a smoke .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Aren ’ t you expecting patients ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s just on five o ’ clock . I don ’ t suppose any one else will come . We might have tea down here .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: How are things going ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rotten . Look here , a wretched two guineas . That ’ s all I ’ ve made this afternoon .

div.stage: PENELOPE comes in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , father ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Kiss your noble parent , my child . You ’ ve got a new dress on .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I rather like it , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Is that another new frock , Pen ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , darling . Why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , nothing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: The wife of a fashionable physician has to spend a lot of money on her clothes .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Dickie was lamenting that times were very bad .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What can you expect with this beastly weather ! Fine , dry , cold day after day . We haven ’ t had a fog this autumn . It doesn ’ t give one a chance . Of course everybody keeps well . Times are getting worse and worse . Everybody has decent drains now . An officious Government gives people pure water . If it weren ’ t for patent medicines and the malade imaginaire half the doctors in London would starve .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Never mind , Dickie . There may be a motor accident just outside our front door one of these days .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It would be just like my luck if they were all killed outright . No , what I want is a really good epidemic , a very complicated form of influenza that ’ d keep people on their backs for about a month .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And supposing I got it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , if you got it that bounder on the other side of the street would have to treat you . And he couldn ’ t charge you as you ’ re my wife , and he ’ d simply grind his teeth at having to waste his time .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: The bounder on the other side of the street is Dr. Rogers . I like him much better than Dickie .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Pompous ass .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: He ’ s got such a pleasant bedside manner .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ ve never seen my bedside manner .Looking at his hands .I say , I must just go and wash my hands , they ’ re covered with Picric Acid .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Where ’ s mother ? Converting the heathen ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: From the safe distance of the Albert Hall .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a change of manner .I ’ m glad you came alone .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Breaking out .I can ’ t go on with it any longer . I ’ ve come to the end of my strength .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Is Dickie still ...?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes . I can ’ t imagine what he sees in her . I sit and watch her sometimes and wonder what she has that I haven ’ t got . You don ’ t think I ’ m plain , do you ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Certainly not . If you had been I should have exposed you at your birth , like the ancient Spartans .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: There are lots of men who are willing to tell me that I ’ m extremely attractive .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Why don ’ t you let them ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear father , you ’ re the most immoral parent I ’ ve ever come across .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a little deprecatory shrug .It might be politic .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Shaking her head .No , I don ’ t know whether I shall ever get Dickie back again , but I don ’ t want to get him back by exciting his jealousy . I don ’ t want his love if I can only have it by making him think other men are in love with me .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Remember that two and two never make five .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Impatiently .It ’ s easy enough to give advice . You ’ ve only got to sit still and watch . I ’ ve got to do things . And the worst of it is that doing things means doing nothing .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Now , father , don ’ t look as if you didn ’ t understand or I shall throw something at your head . It wouldn ’ t be so bad if I could be up and doing , but I just have to sit still and keep my temper . You don ’ t know what I ’ ve suffered this month with a smiling face . I ’ ve laughed while my heart ached . I ’ ve chaffed Dickie when I ’ ve known he was just going to meet Ada Fergusson . I ’ ve arranged little parties so that they might be together . I haven ’ t even dared to cry by myself in case Ada Fergusson should see that my eyes were red and tell Dickie . He ’ s seen her every day , every single day for the last month , and all the time I ’ ve been cheerful and pleasant and amusing .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But how does he manage to get the time ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course he ’ s been neglecting his practice . He ’ s sent his assistant to people he ought to have seen himself . You remember Mrs. Mack , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Smiling .The imaginary Mrs. Mack ? Yes .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: If you knew how I hated Mrs. Mack ! She ’ s been having operations . She has an operation about once a week , and Dickie goes off for the whole day in his car .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: She must have the constitution of a boa-constrictor .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And the curious thing is that she always has an operation when there ’ s a race meeting . She had an operation for the Duke of York ’ s Stakes at Kempton ; and she had another operation for the Cesarewitch , and a third for Sandown .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: How very singular .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It is till you know that Ada Fergusson adores racing . And the thing that makes me so furious is that I ’ m quite certain Dickie puts on her money for her ; and when her horse wins she pockets the profits , and when it loses she doesn ’ t pay her stake .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: That sounds very nasty of her . What makes you think it ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I do it myself .... Poor Dickie , it ’ s going to cost him a lot of money this month .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Because whenever he goes out for the day I have to console myself by buying something . I generally choose something rather dear .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I don ’ t remember that I advised that in the treatment of a volatile husband .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , I added it of my own accord .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But why did you send for me to-day ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Because the end has come . And I can ’ t stand it any longer . This morning Dickie said that Mrs. Mack was well enough to be moved , and he was going to take her over to Paris to put her in the Riviera train .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Do you mean to say that ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With an angry shrug of the shoulders .Ada Fergusson wants a little jaunt in Paris .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m going to tell him he must choose between us . I ’ m going to do everything I can to prevent him from going . And I mean to let him know that if he goes it ’ s the end .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Don ’ t say oh ! Say I ’ m quite right . Say it ’ s the only thing to do .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But I think you ’ re quite wrong .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Wrong !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You don ’ t suppose he wants to go to Paris . No man in his senses would take the risk .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then why is he going ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Because she ’ s making him . And once a woman in these circumstances makes a man do what he doesn ’ t want to , it ’ s the beginning of the end .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How d ’ you know ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I don ’ t know . I guess it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It seems to me that a lifetime spent in the study of mathematics has resulted in some very various knowledge .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Be a good girl , Pen , and let them go .

div.stage: There is a pause while PENELOPE , resting her face on her hands , looks straight at her father . She thinks the matter out .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You were right when you said I should want a great deal of tact , and a great deal of patience , and a great deal of self-control . My word !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Smiling .Well ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll do nothing . I ’ ll hold my tongue , I ’ ll smile , I ’ ll make jokes , but ....

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I want some hats badly . I ’ ll just go and ring up Françoise and tell her to send me all she ’ s got in the shop .

div.stage: DICKIE comes in .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I was just going .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry . Why so soon ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I promised to fetch my wife .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You must come back . This is the first time I ’ ve been separated from Dickie since our marriage , and I shall want to hide my head in the maternal bosom while my noble father pats my hand .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I wish you wouldn ’ t take it so calmly , Pen . You might be a bit cut up .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But , darling , I ’ m making every preparation to have fit after fit of violent hysterics . I can ’ t do more .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rot me , that ’ s right .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With meaning .After all , Dickie , I know you wouldn ’ t go if you could help it . It ’ s only because you feel it ’ s your duty , isn ’ t it ?

div.stage: DICKIE is rather uncomfortable , but says nothing . GOLIGHTLY breaks the momentary silence .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Why are you going by night ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Relieved .Oh , you see , there ’ s so much less of a crowd . It ’ s more convenient when you ’ re carting an invalid about .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Gaily .It ’ ll be great fun , because you ’ ll see all the gay young men who are making a little excursion to Paris with the object of their affections . I ’ m told they always go by night so that no one should see them on the journey .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Well , I must be getting on or I shall be late . Au revoir .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Don ’ t be too long , father , in case my emotions get the better of me before you come back .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Nodding .I may see you later , Dickie .

div.stage: He goes out . PENELOPE makes as if to follow him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m going upstairs to have tea .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rather stiffly .I ’ d like to have a little talk with you , Pen .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then come up into the drawing-room .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ d rather talk to you down here .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Sitting down .Very well . Talk .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You can send for the tea if you like .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No ; I ’ ll let it stand and ruin my digestion .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Taking papers out of his pocket and giving them to PENELOPE .D ’ you know what these are ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a charming smile .Bills , darling ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I can see they ’ re bills , thank you !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Flourishing one of them .This is for the frock I ’ ve got on . You wouldn ’ t think it cost so much , would you ?Looking down at it .You see , you have to pay for the cut .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Trying to keep his temper .And what do you expect me to do with them ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Indifferently .You can put them in the waste-paper basket if you like , but it would be shorter to pay them .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Flying into a passion .Now , look here , Pen . It ’ s perfectly preposterous . You know I ’ m not going to stand this sort of thing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Apparently much astonished , quite good-humouredly .Darling , you ’ re not going to make a scene for a few little things I ’ ve bought myself . I was positively in rags , and I thought you liked me to dress neatly .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hang it all , I ’ m a poor man , and you ’ ve spent more than a hundred and fifty pounds in this one month .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Calmly .Does it come to as much as that ? It ’ s lucky you ’ ve got such a good patient in Mrs. Mack , isn ’ t it ?

div.stage: He gives her a suspicious look , but to get away from MRS. MACK breaks out angrily .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Senseless extravagance I call it . Now look here , here ’ s thirty-five pounds for a dress in blue cloth — absurd price to pay — on 9th of October .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Duke of York ’ s Stakes at Kempton .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How d ’ you mean , Duke of York ’ s Stakes at Kempton ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I just happen to remember they were on that day because Madame Claude was so surprised to see me . It was only by the merest chance that she hadn ’ t gone to the races herself .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But what on earth put it into your head to go and buy a blue cloth dress ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Sweetly .Well , you see , darling , it was the day of the first operation that was performed on Mrs. Mack . And you were away all day , and I felt awfully depressed and lonely . And I knew how anxious you were , and it made me anxious , so I just went and ordered a blue cloth to cheer myself up a bit .

div.stage: DICKIE looks at her for a moment , then looks down at the bill , is about to speak , but says nothing . PENELOPE watches him .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Suddenly .And look here , on the 13th of October there ’ s an ermine stole and a muff .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , that was the second operation on poor Mrs. Mack .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , I think it ’ s a bit thick .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , I had to do something while you were away . And it made me feel so miserable to see everybody driving off with race glasses to Liverpool Street .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You see , the 13th of October was the Cesarewitch .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: And I suppose all the others are to be explained in the same way .Looking at a bill .October 22 .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Sandown Races .

div.stage: DICKIE looks through the bill crossly , but does not speak .
Innocently . ] I wonder why you always had your operations on the same day as an important race meeting .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I suppose you think it odd ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: A little .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , it isn ’ t odd at all . It ’ s one of old Peter Marsden ’ s cranky ways . I told you it was Peter Marsden who did the operations , didn ’ t I ?PENELOPE nods .The fact is , he ’ s simply mad on racing . And he ’ s lost such a pot of money that he always fixes an important operation for the same day as a race meeting so that he absolutely won ’ t be able to go to it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Funny old thing .

div.stage: DICKIE looks up suspiciously .
