With a laugh . ] Peter Marsden , not you , darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Now look here , Pen , we ’ ll say no more about these bills . I ’ ll pay them this time ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I knew you would .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But there must be no more of them .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I really don ’ t know why you should make such a fuss . After all , you ’ ve been earning simply heaps and heaps of money with Mrs. Mack .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: We mustn ’ t count our chickens before they ’ re hatched . I haven ’ t had a penny out of her yet .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But now that she ’ s going away you can send in your bill .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I couldn ’ t possibly . It would kill her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Don ’ t you think you might risk it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think you ’ re awfully heartless , Pen . You forget that I ’ m very much attached to the old lady . I look upon her as a friend as well as a patient .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Perhaps she ’ ll leave you something in her will . We want a new electric brougham , don ’ t we ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I shouldn ’ t accept it . I have the strongest feeling against doctors getting legacies from their patients .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , you ’ ll be able to charge at least a hundred and fifty pounds for taking her to Paris .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a start .Pen !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , you made me jump .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ re not proposing to buy anything more ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , darling , I know that when I get up to-morrow morning and you ’ re not here , I shall feel dreadfully lonely and depressed .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Interrupting .Have your sainted mother to stay with you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And it ’ s struck me that I simply haven ’ t got a hat I can wear .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Sternly .Penelope .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Persuasively .It ’ ll make my frocks last so much longer if I have some nice hats . You see , you ring the changes , and people think you have a new gown on .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: And may I venture to inquire how many hats you ’ ll want to overcome your depression ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Decidedly .Three .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I never heard anything so preposterous .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Now look here , Dickie , I ’ m willing to meet you half way ; I promise you they shan ’ t cost more than five pounds each . You can afford that out of the hundred and fifty .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: The fact is , Pen , that Mrs. Mack is more a friend than a patient , and she ’ s not so well to do as I thought . I ’ m proposing to make no charge for accompanying her to Paris .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Quite firmly .Oh , no , Dickie , I won ’ t hear of it . You ’ ve got a wife to think of — if you died to-morrow I should be totally unprovided for . You have no right to be quixotic . It ’ s not fair to me .

div.stage: DICKIE is just going to answer when PEYTON comes in .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: A lady wishes to see you , sir .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Irritably .At this hour ?

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: It ’ s Mrs. Watson , sir .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I know . Show her in .

div.stage: Exit PEYTON .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Thank heaven , there ’ s somebody . I ’ ll get a few guineas out of her at all events .Looking at his case book .Four visits . That ’ ll be five guineas . By Jove , I want them .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter with her ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know , but I ’ m pretending I do . And she probably won ’ t find out .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll leave you . I must just telephone to some one .

div.stage: She goes out . DICKIE walks up and down irritably . When MRS. WATSON appears he at once puts on his professional manner , and is very bland and affable . MRS. WATSON is a little , old lady in black .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , Mrs. Watson ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: You mustn ’ t mind my coming so late . I know you don ’ t see any one after five , but I ’ m going away .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m delighted to see you . I promise you that .

lg.l: I ’ m starting for the Riviera with my daughter to-morrow , and I thought
I ’ d like to see you again before I went .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course . And how have you been getting on ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: With the keenest satisfaction .Oh ! I don ’ t get on . I never get better .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Have you been taking your medicine regularly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Cheerfully .Yes ; but it doesn ’ t do me any good .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Let ’ s try your knee jerks , shall we ?

div.stage: MRS. WATSON crosses one leg over the other , and DICKIE taps below the knee ; the leg is slightly jerked up .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That seems right enough .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Sir Benjamin Broadstairs tried everything , and he couldn ’ t cure me ; and then I went to Sir William Wilson , and he told me not to do any of the things that Sir Benjamin Broadstairs told me to do , and I got worse and worse !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You seem uncommonly cheerful about it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I ’ ve been to every doctor in London , and they all say I ’ m a wonderful case . I like being examined by doctors , and they take such an interest in me . The hours and hours they ’ ve spent over me . I can never be grateful enough for all the kindness I ’ ve had from them .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s very nice of you to say so . I think I ’ ll try you on something else to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Oh ! make it nice and strong ; won ’ t you , doctor ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You seem to like your medicine with some body in it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Well , I like taking medicines . It ’ s something to do ; and now my daughter ’ s married I ’ m very much alone . I think I ’ ve taken every medicine in the Pharmacopœia , and they ’ ve none of them done me any good .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Handing her a prescription .Well , perhaps this will . You must take it three times a day before meals .

lg.l: Oh ! but I ’ ve had this before , Dr. O ’ Farrell . Sir
Arthur Thomas gave me this only a few months ago .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , try it again . Perhaps you didn ’ t give it a fair chance .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I was reading in the Lancet the other day that a German doctor had discovered a new medicine which does nerve cases such a lot of good . I ’ m sure it ’ s the very thing for me .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What on earth were you reading the Lancet for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Oh , I always read the Lancet and the British Medical Journal . You see , my poor husband had to take them in for his practice .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a gasp .You don ’ t mean to say your husband was a doctor ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Oh , I thought I told you that I was a doctor ’ s widow .

div.stage: DICKIE tries to master his agitation while MRS. WATSON prattles on .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I can never bear to hear doctors spoken badly of . They never do me any good , but they ’ ve been kindness itself . I ’ ve only once been rudely treated , and that — if you ’ ll believe it — was by a mere nobody . I told him all my symptoms , and he said to me , Madam , can you eat ? Yes , I said . I have breakfast in the morning and a little soup at eleven o ’ clock ; and then I have lunch , and I always make a good tea , and I eat a little dinner at half-past seven , and before I go to bed I have some bread and milk . Then he said , Madam , can you sleep ? Yes , I said , for an old woman I sleep very well ; I sleep eight or nine hours regularly . Then he said , Madam , can you walk ? Oh ! yes , I said , I always make a point of walking four miles a day . Then he said , My opinion is that you ’ ve got nothing the matter with you at all . Good afternoon .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Fancy .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Well , I just looked him up and down , and I said to him , Sir , your opinion is not shared by Sir Benjamin Broadstairs , or Sir William Wilson , or Sir Arthur Thomas . And I didn ’ t even offer him a fee , but I just swept out of the room .Archly .You won ’ t give me that new medicine ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Honestly , I don ’ t think it ’ s quite what you want .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Very well . I expect you know best . And now I mustn ’ t take up any more of your time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Sarcastically .Oh , it ’ s of no value , thank you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Persuasively .Will you tell me what I owe you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , as a doctor ’ s widow , of course , I couldn ’ t dream of accepting a fee .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: That is kind of you . But you must allow me to give you a little present .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rather feebly , but brightening up a little .Oh , really , you know ....

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I ’ ve seen every doctor in London of any importance , and they ’ ve none of them charged me a penny , but I always make them a little present . I know that you doctors have to go out in all weathers , and you never wrap yourselves up . So I give them a woollen comforter .

div.stage: She takes out of her bag a large red woollen comforter .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Blankly .Oh , thank you very much .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I made it myself .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Did you !

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: And Sir Benjamin promised to wear his every winter . You ’ ll find it so warm .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m very grateful to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: And now , good-bye , and thank you so much .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: When you come back from the Riviera , you might do worse than consult Dr. Rogers . He lives just at the other end of the street , you know . He ’ s very good in cases like yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Thank you so much .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: She goes out , and he shuts the door . He runs to the other and calls out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Pen ! Pen !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE ’ S VOICE
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: There is a knock at the door .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Irritably .Come in .

div.stage: MRS. WATSON enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I knew there was something I wanted to ask you particularly , and I nearly forgot it . Sir Benjamin Broadstairs said I ought never to eat anything but toast , and Sir William Wilson said he didn ’ t think toast was at all good for me , and I only ought to eat bread . Now , I wonder what I had better do ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Seriously , as if he were deliberating .Well , if I were you , I ’ d eat bread toasted only on one side .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Thank you so much . Good-bye . I hope you ’ ll like the comforter .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m sure I shall . Good-bye .

div.stage: She goes out again , and DICKIE shuts the door .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Pen ! Pen !

div.stage: PENELOPE comes in by the other door .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What is the matter ?

div.stage: DICKIE goes up to her furiously with the comforter in his hands .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Look ! That ’ s my fee ! That !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s a woollen comforter .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Don ’ t be idiotic , Penelope . I can see it ’ s a woollen comforter .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But what ’ s the meaning of it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She ’ s a doctor ’ s widow . Of course I couldn ’ t charge her anything . She kept it dark till to-day . I ’ ll tell you what , doctors ’ widows oughtn ’ t to be allowed to survive their husbands .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: When you ’ re my widow , Pen , you go right up one side of Harley Street and then right down the other and see them all .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But supposing I ’ m not ill ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hang it all , when you ’ ve lost me the least you can do is to enjoy indifferent health .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: If you please , sir , Mrs. Watson says , may she just see you for one minute .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Resigned .Yes .

div.stage: Exit PEYTON .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What the dickens does she want now ?

div.stage: PEYTON shows MRS. WATSON in .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: You ’ ll think you ’ ve never seen the last of me .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Blandly .Not at all . Not at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: I ’ ve been thinking about what you said about toasting my bread on one side .... On which side shall I put the butter ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With his chin in his hand .H ’ m . H ’ m . You must put the butter on the toasted side .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Oh , thank you . Now just one more question , do you think a little jam would hurt me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No , I don ’ t think a little jam would hurt you , but you mustn ’ t put it on the same side as you put the butter .

sp.speaker: MRS. WATSON
sp.p: Oh , thank you . Good afternoon . I ’ m so much obliged .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Not at all . Not at all .

div.stage: MRS. WATSON goes out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Shaking his fist at the door .Suttee .... That ’ s the word . Suttee .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie , what are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ve been trying to think of it for ten minutes . That ’ s what doctors ’ widows ought to do — Suttee . Like the Hindoos .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Burn themselves alive at their husbands ’ death ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ ve hit it . Suttee . That ’ s the word .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But , darling , I should hate to grace your funeral by making a bonfire of myself .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , you have no affection for me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Lots , but that ’ s asking a great deal , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No , you don ’ t care for me as much as you used to . You ’ re quite different . I ’ ve noticed lots of things .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a rapid glance at him , but keeping her chaffing manner .Oh , nonsense .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ ve changed lately . You never come down to see me off in the morning , and you don ’ t ask me at what time I ’ m coming back . You always used to sit on the arm of my chair after breakfast when I was smoking my pipe and reading the paper .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You must have hated it , didn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course I hated it , but it showed you were fond of me , and now that you don ’ t do it any more I miss it .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in , followed by MRS. FERGUSSON , and withdraws .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. Fergusson .

div.stage: DICKIE gives a slight start , and shows faint signs of annoyance . He cannot make out what MRS. FERGUSSON has come for .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: The maid told me you were here , so I asked her to show me straight in . I hope you don ’ t mind .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course not . We ’ re delighted to see you anywhere . Won ’ t you have some tea ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: No , thank you . The fact is , I ’ ve come to see Dr. O ’ Farrell professionally .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You ’ re not ill ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ ve not been very well lately , and I thought I ’ d like to see a doctor .To DICKIE .Will you treat me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ll do anything I can for you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: But it must be really a professional visit . You know , I want to pay .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , nonsense , Dickie couldn ’ t dream of accepting money from one of my friends .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: No , I ’ ve got the strictest principles on that point . I think it ’ s too bad of people to want a doctor to treat them for nothing . I really insist on paying the usual fee .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , well , we ’ ll discuss that later .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll leave you alone , shall I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Do you mind , dear ? It makes me a little uncomfortable to discuss my symptoms before a third party .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: We shall only be five minutes .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I warn you that Dickie ’ s medicines are perfectly beastly .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry you ’ re seedy . You were all right yesterday .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Laughing .I ’ ve never been better in my life , thank you .

div.stage: DICKIE is rather taken aback .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: That ’ s the advantage of you being a doctor . When I want to see you alone I can do it under your wife ’ s very nose . Don ’ t you think it was rather ingenious ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Dryly .Very .

div.stage: She gives a little laugh . She gets up and steps cautiously to the door , and suddenly flings it open .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What on earth are you doing ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I wanted to see if Penelope was listening .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rather sharply .Of course she wasn ’ t listening . That ’ s about the last thing she ’ d do .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , my dear , don ’ t get in a temper about it . Lots of women do listen , you know .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Do they ? I haven ’ t had the pleasure of meeting them .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Fiddle .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Then will you tell me in what way I can be of use to you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Certainly not , if you ask me as crossly as that . You may kiss my hand .He does so .That ’ s right . Still cross ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Do you love me as much as ever ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t say no if you didn ’ t , would you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Brute !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rather impatiently .I say , what on earth have you come for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You are nice to me to-day .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , when I left you yesterday we fixed up everything . I gave you your ticket , and I wrote down the time the train started .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Well , for one thing I wanted to see Penelope .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It amuses me to see her simplicity . I get a lot of pleasure in looking at her and thinking how little she suspects what is going on under her very nose . She ’ s the most trusting person I ever met in my life .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: If you want to know anything , it makes me feel devilish uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: My poor , dear boy , what are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It wouldn ’ t be so bad if we had to take any precautions . But she trusts us absolutely . Why , she ’ s always throwing us together . It never enters her head that there can be the least reason for suspicion . It ’ s like knocking a man down who can ’ t defend himself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I suppose that means that you no longer love me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course I love you . Good heavens , I ’ ve told you so till I ’ m blue in the face .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , no , you no longer love me . Men only begin to have scruples when they stop caring for you .

div.stage: DICKIE gives a sigh of resignation . This is not the first scene he has had to put up with .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ ve sacrificed everything for your sake . And now you insult me . And when I think of my poor husband bravely serving his country in a foreign land ! Oh , it ’ s cruel , cruel !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But I ’ ve only said it made me feel low down to treat Penelope badly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You don ’ t think of my feelings . You don ’ t think how I feel . What about my husband ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , you see I don ’ t happen to know your husband , and I do know my wife .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Don ’ t be so stupid . Of course you know your wife .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s why I don ’ t like behaving like an utter cad .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: If you really loved me you would think of nothing but me , nothing , nothing , nothing .

div.stage: She puts her handkerchief to her eyes .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I say , don ’ t cry .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I shall cry . I ’ ve never been treated like this before . If you don ’ t love me any more , why don ’ t you say so ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , I do love you . But ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: But what ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Nervously .Well — er — I think it would be much better if we — put the trip to Paris off for a bit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Gasping with anger .Oh ! Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Penelope ’ s so blindly confident .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ ll never speak to you again . I wish I had never met you . Oh , how can you insult me like this !

div.stage: She begins to sob .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , Lord ! Oh , Lord ! I say , don ’ t cry . I didn ’ t mean to be horrid . I ’ m awfully sorry .

div.stage: He tries to take away her hands from her face .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Don ’ t touch me . Don ’ t come near me .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ll do anything you like if you won ’ t cry . I say , just think if Penelope came in — I was only thinking of the risk to you . Of course , there ’ s nothing I ’ d like so much as a jaunt over the Channel .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Is that true ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Do you really want me to come ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course I do , if you don ’ t mind the risk .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With a smile .Oh , I ’ ll make that all right .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Why , what are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Wait a minute or two and you ’ ll see .

div.stage: She is perfectly composed again , and in high good-humour .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: We might tell Penelope that we ’ re ready .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Very well .As DICKIE goes to the door .Oh , I quite forgot . I ’ ve simply got a head like a sieve .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Well , I almost forgot the very thing I came to see you about . And all through you making a scene .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Did I make a scene ? I wasn ’ t aware of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I want to ask you something . You won ’ t be angry , will you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t think so .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Of course it ’ s nothing very important really , but it ’ s just a little awkward to ask .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , nonsense . Of course I ’ ll do anything I can .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Well , a friend of mine on the Stock Exchange gave me a splendid tip , and ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It hasn ’ t come off . I know those splendid tips .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , but it ’ s bound to be all right , only there are some differences to pay . I don ’ t quite understand what it all means , but Solly Abrahams ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Interrupting .Is that your friend on the Stock Exchange ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Yes , why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , nothing . Good old Scotch name , that ’ s all .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Solly says I must send him a cheque for a hundred and eighty pounds .

div.stage: DICKIE gives a slight start , and his face falls .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: And it ’ s just a little awkward for me to pay that just now . You see my income is always paid me half-yearly , and I really haven ’ t got a hundred and eighty pounds in the bank . I never borrow — it ’ s a thing I can ’ t bear — and I felt the only person I could come to now was you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m sure that ’ s awfully nice of you , not to say flattering .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I knew you ’ d give it me at once , and , of course , I ’ ll pay you back out of my profits .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s very good of you . I ’ ll see what I can do .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Would it be too much trouble if I asked you to write out a cheque now ? It ’ ll be such a weight off my mind .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course . I ’ ll be only too glad . By the way , what are the shares called ?

div.stage: He sits down at his desk and writes a cheque .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s a gold mine . It ’ s called the Johannesburg and New Jerusalem .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: The name inspires confidence .

div.stage: He gives her the cheque .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Thanks , so much . It ’ s awfully good of you . Now just write out a little prescription so as to have something to show Penelope .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You forget nothing .

div.stage: He writes .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: And I must give you a fee .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I wouldn ’ t bother about that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh yes , I insist . Besides , it makes it look so much more probable .

div.stage: She looks in her purse .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , how stupid of me ! I ’ ve only got a two-shilling bit in my purse . You don ’ t happen to have a couple of sovereigns on you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I think I have . The only money I ’ ve earned to-day .

div.stage: He takes them out of his pocket and gives them to Mrs. Fergusson . She puts them on the desk with a two-shilling piece .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Thank you .... There . That looks a most imposing fee . You must leave it on there for Penelope to see .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Shall I call her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I will .She goes to the door and calls .Penelope , we ’ ve quite done .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hearing voices upstairs .Hulloa , there ’ s our Uncle Davenport .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , I met him in the park the other day . He made himself so pleasant . He asked me if I was a Fergusson of Glengary . I didn ’ t know what he meant , but I said I was , and he seemed so pleased .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ d better not let him know you were a Miss Jones or he ’ ll have a fit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , I shall tell him I ’ m a Jones of Llandudno . I think that sounds rather smart .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You have what one might politely describe as a remarkable power of invention .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I don ’ t know about that , but I am a womanly woman , and that ’ s why men like me .

div.stage: PENELOPE and BARLOW come in .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Ah , Mrs. Fergusson , this is a delightful surprise .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You wicked , wicked man , I am told you ’ re such a rake .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Uncle Davenport ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Delighted .Ah , ah . Tales out of school , Mrs. Fergusson .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: If I ’ d known what a reputation you had I wouldn ’ t have let you talk to me for half an hour in the park .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Bubbling over with delight .Oh , you mustn ’ t listen to all you hear . A man who goes out as much as I do is sure to get talked about . Our world is so small and so censorious .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Dr. O ’ Farrell has been writing a prescription for me . I haven ’ t been very well lately .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m very sorry to hear that . You look the picture of health and extremely handsome .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , you horrid cruel thing ! I wanted you to sympathise with me and tell me how ill I looked .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: If you will allow me to call on you I can promise to sympathise with you , but I ’ m afraid I shall never be able to tell you that you look anything but charming .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: That ’ s too nice of you . You must come and see me the moment I get back from Paris .

div.stage: DICKIE gives a start .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Are you going to Paris ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I came on purpose to tell you . Really , I ’ ve got a head like a sieve . Poor Mrs. Mack has asked me if I would go as far as Paris with her . A most unfortunate thing has happened . Her maid ’ s mother has suddenly died , and the poor thing naturally wants to go to the funeral . And so ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Mrs. Mack has asked you to go in her maid ’ s place ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Only for two days , of course . Now , I want to know , dear , tell me honestly , do you mind ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Some women are so funny . I thought you mightn ’ t like the idea of my going with Dr. O ’ Farrell as far as Paris , and , of course , we shall be travelling back together .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What nonsense ! Of course , I ’ m only too glad . It ’ ll be so nice for Dickie to have some one to travel with .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Then that settles it . I like to do everything above board , you know .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Seeing the guineas on the desk .I see you ’ ve been raking in the shekels , Dickie .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s my fee . I insisted on paying a fee — I particularly want you to know that , Penelope — I ’ m so scrupulous about that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , but Dickie can ’ t accept it .To DICKIE .You are a grasping old thing !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m sure I didn ’ t want the money .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You really must take it back , Ada .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Putting up a defensive hand .No , I couldn ’ t really . It ’ s one of my principles .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I know your principles are excellent , but I really shouldn ’ t like Dickie to accept a fee for seeing my greatest friend .

div.stage: PENELOPE takes up the money and gives it to MRS. FERGUSSON .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , well , of course , if you take it like that , I don ’ t know what to do .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Put it in your purse and say no more about it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s too good of you .

div.stage: She puts it in her purse . DICKIE ’ S face falls as he sees his own money disappearing .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: And now I must really fly .Holding out her hand to BARLOW .Good-bye . Don ’ t forget to come and see me , but , remember , I shall expect to hear all about that little ballet-girl .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Delighted to be thought so gay .You mustn ’ t ask me to be indiscreet .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: To PENELOPE .Good-bye , dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ll come to the door with you .

div.stage: PENELOPE and MRS. FERGUSSON go out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Going to the telephone .I don ’ t believe you ’ ve ever known a ballet-girl in your life .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: No , but it pleases women of our class to think one is hand and glove with persons of that profession .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Central 1234 . If they only knew that nine ballet-girls out of ten go home every night to their children and a husband in the suburbs ! I just want to ring up my broker . Is that you , Robertson ? I say , d ’ you know anything about a mine called the Johannesburg and New Jerusalem ? Rotten ? I thought as much . That ’ s all , thank you .He puts on the receiver — to himself , acidly .A hundred and eighty pounds gone bang .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Look here , Dickie , now that you have a moment to spare you might give me a little professional advice . Of course , I shan ’ t pay you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Good Lord ! I might as well be a hospital . I ’ m not even supported by voluntary contributions .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: The fact is , I ’ ve noticed lately that I ’ m not so thin as I was .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It can ’ t have required great perspicacity to notice that .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I ’ m not asking you for repartee , Dickie , but advice .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You don ’ t want to bother about a figure at your time of life .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: To tell you the truth , I have an inkling that I ’ ve made something of an impression on a very charming lady ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Interrupting .Take my advice and marry her quickly before the impression wears off .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Strange as it may appear to you , she ’ s a married woman .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Then don ’ t hesitate — do a bolt .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: What do you mean , Dickie ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: My dear Uncle Davenport , I ’ m young enough to be your son ; philandering with a married woman is the most exaggerated form of amusement that ’ s ever been invented . Take care ! That ’ s all I say . Take care !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She ’ ll bind you hand and foot , and put a halter round your neck and lead you about by it . She ’ ll ask you ten times a day if you love her , and each time you get up to go away she ’ ll make a scene to force you to stay longer . Each time you put on your hat she ’ ll pin you down to the exact hour of your next visit .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But all women do that . It only shows that they like you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , I suppose all women do that — except Pen . Pen never bothers . She never asks you if you love her . She never keeps you when you want to get away . She never insists on knowing all your movements . And when you leave her she never asks that fatal , fiendish question , at what time will you be back ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Well , my boy , if my wife were as indifferent to me as that , I should ask myself who the other feller was .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What the dickens do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear Dickie , it ’ s woman ’ s nature to be exacting . If she ’ s in love with you she ’ s always a nuisance , and a very charming nuisance too , to my mind . I like it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You are not suggesting that Penelope ....

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Now , my dear boy , I didn ’ t come to talk to you about Penelope , but about my own health .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , you ’ ve got chronic adiposity . That ’ s all that ’ s the matter with you .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Good gracious me , that sounds very alarming . And what shall I do for it ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Savagely , very quickly .Give up wines , spirits and liqueurs , bread , butter , milk , cream , sugar , potatoes , carrots , cauliflowers , peas , turnips , rice , sago , tapioca , macaroni , jam , honey , and marmalade .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But that ’ s not treatment , that ’ s homicide !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Taking no notice .Put on a sweater and run round the park every morning before breakfast . Let ’ s have a look at your liver .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But , my dear Dickie ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Lie down on that sofa . Now don ’ t make a fuss about it . I ’ m not going to kill you .BARLOW lies down .Put your knees up .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: As DICKIE feels his liver .She ’ s a fine , dashing woman . There ’ s no doubt about that .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Let yourself go quite loose . Who ’ s a fine , dashing woman ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Mrs. Fergusson .

div.stage: DICKIE starts . He gives BARLOW a look , and then walks away , open-mouthed .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Dickie , Dickie .

div.stage: Much alarmed he gets off the sofa .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Is my liver very wrong ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Completely abstracted .It ’ s in a beastly state . I thought it would be .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: In tragic tones .Richard , tell me the worst at once .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Impatiently .Don ’ t be such an old donkey . Your liver ’ s as right as mine is . There ’ s nothing the matter with you except that you do yourself too well , and don ’ t take enough exercise .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: With unction .I suppose one has to pay for being the most popular diner-out of one ’ s time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Looking at him sharply .Is it on Mrs. Fergusson that you ’ ve made something of an impression ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: With great self-satisfaction .My dear fellow , I am the last man to give a woman away .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Between ourselves , Dickie , do you think Mrs. Fergusson would find it peculiar if I asked her to lunch with me tête-à-tête at the Carlton ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Peculiar ! She ’ d jump at it .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Do you think her husband would mind ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , her husband ’ s all right . He keeps on bravely serving his country in a foreign land .

lg.l: It shows that she has a nice nature , or she wouldn ’ t have come to ask
Penelope if she minded your going to Paris together .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , she has a charming nature .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Lucky dog , I wish I were going to Paris with her .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Fervently .I wish you were .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Ha , ha . Well , well , I must be running away . I ’ m dining out as usual . These good duchesses , they will not leave me alone . Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes out . DICKIE walks up and down the room thinking . In a moment PENELOPE puts her head in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I say , darling , oughtn ’ t you to be packing ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Come in and let ’ s smoke a cigarette together .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: All right .

div.stage: She takes a cigarette , which he lights for her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I hope you ’ ll have a splendid time in Paris .

div.stage: She sits down .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You never sit on the arm of my chair as you used to .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m horribly afraid I ’ m growing middle-aged . I ’ ve discovered how much more comfortable it is to have a chair of my own .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Trying to hide a slight embarrassment .Weren ’ t you rather surprised when Mrs. Fergusson told you she was going to Paris to-night ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Surprised ?

div.stage: PENELOPE gives a little gurgle , tries to stifle it but cannot , then , giving way , bursts into peal upon peal of laughter . DICKIE watches her with increasing astonishment .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What on earth are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Bubbling over .Darling , you must think me an old silly . Of course , I knew you were going together .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Thoroughly startled .I don ’ t know what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I have tried not to see anything , but you do make it so difficult .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Making up his mind to be very haughty .Will you have the goodness to explain yourself ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear , of course I know all about it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I entirely fail to gather your meaning . What do you know all about ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: About you and Ada , silly .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Very haughtily .Penelope , do you mean to say you suspect me of ...?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With an affectionate smile .Darling !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Suddenly alarmed .What d ’ you know ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Everything .

div.stage: He gives a gasp and looks at PENELOPE anxiously .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ve been so amused to watch you during the last two months .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Amused ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Upon my word , it ’ s been as good as a play .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Quite at a loss .Have you known all along ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear , didn ’ t you see that I did everything in the world to throw you together ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But I assure you there ’ s not a word of truth in it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Come , come , Dickie !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But why haven ’ t you said anything ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I thought it would only embarrass you . I didn ’ t mean to say anything to-day , but I couldn ’ t help laughing when you asked me if I was surprised .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Aren ’ t you angry ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Angry ? What about ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Aren ’ t you jealous ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Jealous ? You must think me a little donkey .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You took it as a matter of course ? It amused you ? It was as good as a play ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Darling , we ’ ve been married for five years . It ’ s absurd to think there could be anything between us after all that time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , is it ? I wasn ’ t aware of that fact .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: The whole thing seemed to me of no importance . I was pleased to think you were happy .

lg.l: Well , I think it ’ s positively disgraceful ,
Penelope .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , my dear , don ’ t exaggerate . It was a harmless peccadillo .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m not talking of my behaviour , but of yours .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Mine ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , scandalous I call it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Quite disappointed .And I thought it was so tactful .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Tactful be blowed . You must be entirely devoid of any sense of decency .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear , I haven ’ t done anything .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s just it . You ought to have done something . You ought to have kicked up a row ; you ought to have made scenes ; you ought to have divorced me . But just to sit there and let it go on as if it were nothing at all ! It ’ s too monstrous .

lg.l: I ’ m awfully sorry . If I ’ d known you wanted me to make a scene of course
I would have , but really it didn ’ t seem worth making a fuss about .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ve never heard anything so callous , anything so cold-blooded , anything so cynical .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You are difficult to please .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But don ’ t you realise that I ’ ve treated you abominably .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , you ’ ve always been the best and most discreet of husbands .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No , I ’ ve been a bad husband . I ’ m man enough to acknowledge it . And I mean to turn over a new leaf , Penelope ; I will give Ada up . I promise you never to see her again .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Darling , why should you cause her needless pain ? After all , she ’ s an old friend of mine . I think the least I can expect is that you should treat her nicely .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say you want it to go on ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s an arrangement that suits us all three . It amuses you , Ada has some one to take her about , and I get a lot of new frocks .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Frocks ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , you see , I ’ ve been consoling my aching heart by replenishing my wardrobe .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: So you ’ re willing to sacrifice our whole happiness to your frocks . Oh , I ’ ve cherished a viper in my bosom . I may have acted like a perfect beast , but , hang it all , I do know what ’ s right and wrong . I have a moral sense .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It seems to have displaced your sense of humour .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Do you know that all these weeks I ’ ve been tortured with remorse ? I ’ ve told myself every day that I was treating you shamefully , I ’ ve not had a moment ’ s happiness . I ’ ve lived on a perfect rack .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It doesn ’ t seem to have had any serious effect on your health .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: And here have you been laughing up your sleeve all the time . It can ’ t go on .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Upon my word , I don ’ t see why not ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: We ’ ve been mistaken in one another . I ’ m not the man to stand such a position with indifference . And I ’ ve been mistaken in you , Penelope . I thought you cared for me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I dote upon you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s a jolly nice way of showing it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That ’ s just what I thought it was .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ ve outraged all my better nature .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then what do you propose to do ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m going to do the only possible thing . Separate .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Hearing voices in the hall .Here are papa and mamma . They said they were coming back .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I hope they ’ ll never find out what a wicked , cruel woman you are . It would send down their grey hairs in sorrow to the grave .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But , my dear , they know all about it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What ! Is there any one who doesn ’ t know ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: We didn ’ t tell Uncle Davenport . He ’ s such a man of the world , he has no sense of humour .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in to announce the GOLIGHTLYS , then goes out .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Professor and Mrs. Golightly .

div.stage: The GOLIGHTLYS come in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Kissing MRS. GOLIGHTLY .Well , mother ... Papa , Dickie wants to separate from me because I won ’ t divorce him .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: That doesn ’ t sound very logical .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What has happened ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Nothing ’ s happened . I can ’ t make out why Dickie ’ s so cross .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Indignantly .Nothing !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I didn ’ t mean to say anything about it , but Dickie found out that we knew all about his little love affair .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , how tactless of you ! A man likes to keep those things from his wife .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: And d ’ you know the attitude Penelope takes up ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: She hasn ’ t been making a scene ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s just it . Any woman of feeling would make a scene . There must be something radically wrong about her , or she would have wept and stamped and torn her hair .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Mildly .Oh , my dear boy , don ’ t you exaggerate the enormity of your offence ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: There are no excuses for me .

lg.l: It was a mere trifle . It would show a lamentable want of humour in
Penelope if she took it seriously .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say you agree with her ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear fellow , we ’ re in the twentieth century .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh ! Mrs. Golightly , you spend your time in converting the heathen . Don ’ t you think your own family needs some of your attention ?

div.stage: PENELOPE , unseen by DICKIE , makes a face at MRS. GOLIGHTLY to induce her to keep up the scene .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: A long acquaintance with savage races has led me to the conclusion that man is naturally a polygamous animal .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: My brain reels .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I confess I was relieved to hear it was a married woman . It seems to make it so much more respectable .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It appears to me I ’ m the only moral man here .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie , darling , I haven ’ t been having an affair with the policeman .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I wish you had . I wouldn ’ t have treated you like this .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I thought of it , but I didn ’ t like the colour of his moustache .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I know I ’ m to blame . I ’ ve behaved like a perfect brute .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , nonsense .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Don ’ t contradict , Penelope . I ’ m thoroughly ashamed of myself .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Come , come !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I repeat , there are no excuses for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Poor fellow , he seems quite cut up .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I haven ’ t a leg to stand on , but , by Jove , I ’ ve got a moral sense , and I tell you all that I ’ m simply outraged . You ’ re overthrowing the foundations of society . Whatever I ’ ve done , I ’ ve got more respect for the sanctity of the home and the decencies of family life than all of you put together .

div.stage: He flings towards the door , stops , and turns round to shake his fist at them .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: A moral sense . That ’ s what I ’ ve got .

div.stage: He goes out , slamming the door behind him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a laugh .Poor darling .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: What on earth made you blurt it all out ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: She came here to-day , and I saw that he was sick to death of her .... Mamma , you behaved like a heroine of romance .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I shall never forgive myself for the dreadful things you ’ ve made me say .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , yes , you will , mother . Fast an extra day all through next Lent . It ’ ll be equally good for your soul and for your figure .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Penelope !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To GOLIGHTLY .I suddenly felt the moment had come .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Take care .

div.stage: DICKIE bursts violently into the room .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , what are these two confounded women doing in the hall ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What women ? Oh , I know ....She goes to the door .Please come in . They ’ re from Françoise . The Modiste .

div.stage: The girls come in , laden with hat boxes .

lg.l: You told me I might get a hat or two to console myself for your trip to
Paris .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Very nice of you , Dickie . That shows you haven ’ t a selfish nature .

div.stage: PENELOPE makes another face at her mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You ’ ve never given me a free hand to buy hats , Charles .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: On the other hand , I ’ ve never taken little jaunts to Paris without you , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Some women are so lucky in their husbands .

div.stage: Meanwhile the girls have been taking hats out , and PENELOPE puts one on . She is perfectly delighted .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , isn ’ t this a dream ?Looking at the other .Oh ! oh ! Did you ever see anything so lovely ? Dickie , you are a dear . I ’ m so glad you ’ re going to Paris .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Furiously .I ’ m not going to Paris .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Take all these hats away .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But Mrs. Mack ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Mrs. Mack can go to the devil .

div.stage: He seizes the telephone .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hulloa , hulloa . Gerrard 1234 . Tell Mrs. Fergusson that Mrs. Mack has had a relapse , and will not be able to go to Paris to-night .

div.stage: END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : PENELOPE ’ S boudoir . It is an attractive room , furnished with bright-coloured chintzes , and gay with autumn flowers and great bunches of leaves . There is a large looking-glass . It is a room to live in , and there are books and magazines scattered about . Photographs of DICKIE in every imaginable attitude .

PEN , in a ravishing costume , is alone , standing in the middle of the room . She looks at herself in the glass and turns right round , smiling with satisfaction . She preens herself . Suddenly she sees something she does not quite like ; she frowns a little , then she makes a face at herself , solemnly and elaborately curtsies , and gaily throws herself a kiss .
PEYTON comes in , followed by the GOLIGHTLYS .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Professor and Mrs. Golightly .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Stretching out her arms .Oh , my sainted mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Out of breath .I ’ ve never climbed up so many stairs in my life .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I told Peyton to bring you up here so that no one should come and bother us .With a dramatic gesture .My noble father !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My chiyld !

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Don ’ t be ridiculous , Pen .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Sit down , mamma , and get your breath back , because I ’ m just going to take it away again .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: It sounds hardly worth while .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie adores me .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But it ’ s the most surprising , exquisite , wonderful thing in the world , and I ’ m in the seventh heaven of delight .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But has he told you so ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , we ’ re not on speaking terms at present .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Ah , I suppose you express your mutual affection in dumb show .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: He went out immediately after you left last night , and didn ’ t come home till past twelve . I heard him stop at my door , so I huddled myself under the bed-clothes and pretended to be fast asleep , but I just let my hand drop carelessly over one side of the bed . Then he gave a tiny little knock , and as I didn ’ t answer he came in , and he crept up on tip-toe , and he looked at me as if — as if he ’ d like to eat me up .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Penelope , you ’ re romancing . How on earth could you know that ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Putting her finger at the back of her head .I saw him through the back of my head — there . And then he bent down and just touched my hand with his lips .Showing her hand to GOLIGHTLY .Look , that ’ s where he kissed it — just on the knuckle .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Gravely looking at her hand .It seems to have left no mark .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Don ’ t be silly . And then he crept softly out again , and I had the first really good sleep I ’ ve had for a month . And this morning I had my breakfast in bed , and when I got up he ’ d gone out .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You haven ’ t seen him to-day at all ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , he didn ’ t come in to luncheon .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Well , Charles , I ’ m grateful that you never showed your passion for me by keeping systematically out of my way .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But , my dear , it ’ s so simple . Of course , he ’ s in a dreadful temper . I ’ ve made him feel a perfect fool , and he hates it . But , good heavens ! after five years I know how to deal with him when I ’ ve hurt his pride . I ’ ll just give him a chance of saving his face , and then we ’ ll fall into one another ’ s arms and be happy ever afterwards .

div.stage: GOLIGHTLY , who has been sitting near a table , draws a sheet of paper towards him and begins , meditatively , to write .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: But , darling , don ’ t waste the precious hours , do it at once .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , I ’ m wiser than that . I ’ m not going to do anything till Ada Fergusson is quite disposed of .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Has anything been seen of her ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , but I expect her here every minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a gasp .Here ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: She rang up last night and spokeimitating a man ’ s tonesin a deep voice , like this , so that I shouldn ’ t recognise her . She asked if Dickie was at home , and I said he wasn ’ t .Imitating the man ’ s voice again .Will you ask him to ring up Mrs. Mack as soon as he comes back ? Oh ! I said , I think he ’ s been at Mrs. Mack ’ s all the evening , and I rang off quickly . And this morning I just took the receiver off , and I think by now Ada must be in a pretty temper .

div.stage: She catches sight of GOLIGHTLY and goes up to look at what he is writing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Tapping the table sharply with her open hand .Two and two don ’ t make five , father .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I never said they did , darling .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then why are you writing it down ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You seem to think they do , my dear ; and I have the highest respect for your intelligence .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Mamma , if you thought it absolutely necessary to provide a father for your offspring , I wish you had chosen one who wasn ’ t quite so irritating .

div.stage: GOLIGHTLY does not answer , but quietly adds two and two together . PENELOPE watches him for a moment .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: D ’ you think I ’ m a perfect fool , father ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Yes , my dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: You ’ re preparing for Dickie once more an uninterrupted diet of strawberry ices .

div.stage: PENELOPE goes up to her father and sits down opposite to him . She takes the pencil out of his hand .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Put that down , father , and tell me what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Joining his hands and leaning back in his chair .How are you going to keep your husband ’ s love now you have got it back ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a nod and a smile .I ’ m never going to bore him with demonstrations of affection . I ’ m never going to ask him if he loves me . And when he goes out I ’ m never going to inquire at what time he ’ ll be back .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Calmly .And what will you do when the next pretty little grass-widow throws herself at his head ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Rather outraged at the mere thought .I hope he ’ ll duck and dodge her .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a deprecating shrug of the shoulders .Your mother , from her unrivalled knowledge of heathen races , has told you that man is naturally a polygamous animal .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I shall never forgive myself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do you mean to say I ’ m to expect Dickie to have flirtations with half a dozen different women ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I only see one way to avoid it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And what is that ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Be half a dozen different women yourself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It sounds dreadfully exhausting .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Remember that man is by nature a hunter . But how the dickens can he pursue if you ’ re always flinging yourself in his arms ? Even the barndoor hen gives her lawful mate a run for his money .

div.stage: PENELOPE looks from her father to her mother . She gives a little sigh .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It was so easy for me to love , honour , and obey him , and so delightful . It never struck me that I ought to keep watch over my feelings .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: We all strive for happiness , but what would happiness be if it clung to us like a poor relation ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Nodding her head .Strawberry ice for breakfast , strawberry ice for luncheon , and strawberry ice for tea .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Put a Rembrandt on your walls , and in a week you ’ ll pass it without a glance .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Pulling out deprecating hands .Papa , don ’ t batter me with metaphors .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a smile .Well , you made your love too cheap , my dear . You should have let your husband beg for it , and you made it a drug in the market . Dole out your riches . Make yourself a fortress that must be freshly stormed each day . Let him never know that he has all your heart . He must think always that at the bottom of your soul there is a jewel of great price that is beyond his reach .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do you mean to say that I must be always on my guard ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: A wise woman never lets her husband be quite , quite sure of her . The moment he is —with a shrug of the shoulders— Cupid puts on a top-hat and becomes a churchwarden .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Huskily .D ’ you think it ’ s worth all that ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: That is a question only you can answer .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I suppose you mean it depends on how much I love Dickie .A pause . Tremulously .I love him with all my heart , and if I can keep his love everything is worth while .She rests her face on her hands , and looks straight in front of her . Her voice is filled with tears .But , oh , father , why can ’ t we go back to the beginning when we loved one another without a thought of wisdom or prudence ? That was the real love . Why couldn ’ t it last ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Tenderly .Because you and Dickie are man and woman , my dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a flash of her old spirit .But my friends have husbands , and they don ’ t philander with every pretty woman they meet .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Scylla and Charybdis . The price they pay is satiety . Would you rather have the placid indifference of nine couples out of ten , or at the cost of a little trouble and a little common sense keep Dickie loving you passionately to the end of his days ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a roguish twinkle .You and mamma show no signs of being bored to death with one another .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Your sainted mother has been systematically unfaithful to me for twenty years .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Charles !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: She has had an affair with the Additional Curates ’ Society , and an intrigue with the English Church Mission . She has flirted with Christian Science , made eyes at Homœopathy , and her relations with vegetarianism have left a distinct mark on her figure . How could I help adoring a woman so depraved ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Good-humouredly .It ’ s monstrous of you to reproach me , Charles , when you have conducted for years a harem of algebraical symbols .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Lifting up her hands in mock horror .And to think that I never knew how immoral my parents were !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Patting his wife ’ s hand .I think we must be the lucky ones , dear . We ’ ve been married for twenty years ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Interrupting .Make it a quarter of a century , father . I really can ’ t pass for less than twenty-four .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: To his wife .And we seem to have got on pretty well , don ’ t we ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Affectionately .You ’ ve been very good to me , Charles , dear .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: We ’ ve clomb the hill together ....

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Sh ! sh ! sh ! I cannot allow my parents to flirt in my presence . I never heard of such a thing .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: We tender our apologies .

lg.l: Listen . There ’ s Dickie . Father , quickly — what must
I do to make him love me always ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: In two words , lead him a devil of a life .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Ruefully .If you only knew how I want to fly into his arms and forget the wretched past !

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Don ’ t , but tell him you ’ re going for a motor trip .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Her face falling .Supposing he lets me go ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: My dear , a merciful providence has given you roguish eyes and a sharp tongue . Make use of them .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Charles , I shall be thankful when you return to your mathematics . The morals of that hussy X are already so bad that you can ’ t make them much worse .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: The fact is , papa , that as a guide for the young you have rather advanced views .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: With a grotesque , dramatic flourish .Ungrateful child ! And I , like the pelican , have offered you my very heart to dine on .

div.stage: DICKIE comes in . He is a little embarrassed and uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes , do !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Nodding to the GOLIGHTLYS .How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: To his wife .Are you ready ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Getting up .Yes .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I hope I ’ m not driving you away .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Oh no , we only came in for ten minutes to say good-bye to Penelope .

div.stage: DICKIE , rather puzzled at this , gives PENELOPE a quick look .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Are you ...?He stops .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: I hope you ’ ll enjoy yourself , dear .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m sure I shall .

sp.speaker: MRS. GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Good-bye , darling .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Kissing her mother .Good-bye .

div.stage: She goes to the bell and rings it .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: We can find our way out . Don ’ t bother about Peyton .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I want to speak to her .

sp.speaker: GOLIGHTLY
sp.p: Oh , I see .Nodding to DICKIE .Good-bye .

div.stage: The GOLIGHTLYS go out . PENELOPE , with a slight smile , lies down on the sofa and takes up a magazine . She pays no attention to DICKIE . He gives her a sidelong glance and arranges his tie in the glass . PEYTON comes in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Looking up from her magazine .Oh , Peyton , you might pack up some things for me in that little flat portmanteau of the doctor ’ s . Put my green charmeuse in .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Very well , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You can call a cab in half an hour .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Very well , ma ’ am .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Are you going away ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , yes , didn ’ t I tell you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Stiffly .No .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How stupid of me ! You see , I was expecting you to spend two or three days in Paris with Ada , and I arranged to motor down to Cornwall with the Hendersons .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But I gave up the trip to Paris so as not to annoy you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling .It wouldn ’ t have annoyed me a bit , darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ought to have annoyed you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: In any case I ’ m afraid I can ’ t throw the Hendersons over . They ’ ve made up a little partie carrée so that we can play bridge in the evenings .

div.stage: DICKIE goes up to PEN and sits on the sofa beside her .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Look here , Pen , let ’ s make it up .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Quite pleasantly .But we haven ’ t quarrelled , have we ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a smile .I don ’ t know whether I want to shake you or hug you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , if I were you , I ’ d do neither .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Taking her hands .Pen , I want to talk seriously to you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Releasing them , with a look at the clock .Have you time ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What on earth d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You generally start off for Mrs. Mack ’ s about now .

div.stage: DICKIE gets up and walks up and down the room .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Resolutely .Mrs. Mack ’ s dead .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Jumping off the sofa .Dead ! When ’ s the funeral ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: The date hasn ’ t been settled yet .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Well , now you ’ ll be able to send in your bill .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Nervously .Pen , Mrs. Mack never existed .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a smile .I never thought she did , darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What !

div.stage: PENELOPE giggles .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say you knew all the time that I ’ d invented her ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I thought it was very nice of you to make up a plausible excuse for being away so much .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Then , when you bought all those things because I was making such a pot of money , you were just pulling my leg .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a smile .Well ....

div.stage: DICKIE suddenly bursts into a shout of laughter .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: When he recovers .I say , you have scored us off . Upon my soul , you are a wonderful little woman . I can ’ t think how I ever saw anything in Ada Fergusson .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , but I think she ’ s charming .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What nonsense ! You know you don ’ t . If you only knew the life she led me !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I suppose she often asked you if you really loved her ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Ten times a day .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And when you left her , did she want to know exactly at what time you ’ d come back ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How did you know ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I guessed it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Going towards her as if to take her in his arms .Oh , Pen , let ’ s forget and forgive .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Getting out of his way .There ’ s nothing to forgive , darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Making a step towards her .I suppose you want me to eat the dust .... I have behaved like a perfect brute . I ’ m awfully sorry , and I ’ ll never do it again .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Eluding him as though by accident .I daresay the game isn ’ t worth the candle .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Trying to intercept her .Don ’ t speak of it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Keeping out of his reach .And I was under the impression you were having such a good time .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I was feeling awfully conscience-stricken .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That ’ s where women have such an advantage over men . Their conscience never strikes them till they ’ ve lost their figure and their complexion .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Stopping .I say , what are you running round the room for in that ridiculous fashion ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I thought we were playing touch-last .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Don ’ t be a little beast , Pen . You know you love me , and I simply dote upon you .... I can ’ t do more than I have done .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What d ’ you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I want you to kiss and make friends .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Quite good-naturedly .I think you ’ re a little previous , aren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I suppose you ’ re thinking of Ada Fergusson .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I confess she hadn ’ t entirely slipped my mind .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hang Ada Fergusson !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I think that ’ s rather drastic punishment . After all , she did nothing but succumb to your fatal fascination .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: That ’ s right , put all the blame on me . As if it were men who made the running on these occasions ! I never want to see her again .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How changeable you are .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Going towards her eagerly .I ’ m never going to change again . I ’ ve had my lesson , and I ’ m going to be good in future .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Getting a chair between herself and him .Anyhow , don ’ t you think you ’ d better be off with the old love before you get on with the new ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes , but you might help me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You don ’ t want me by any chance to tell Ada Fergusson that you don ’ t care for her any more ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s a devilish awkward thing to say oneself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I can imagine that the best-tempered woman would take it a little amiss .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , can ’ t you suggest something to help me out ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .My dear , since the days of Ariadne there ’ s only been one satisfactory way of consoling a deserted maiden .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a jump .Uncle Davenport !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What about Uncle Davenport ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: He told me yesterday he thought she was a devilish fine woman .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , no , Dickie , I ’ m not going to allow you to sacrifice my only uncle .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ll just ring him up and tell him she ’ s not gone to Paris .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , Dickie . No , Dickie . No , Dickie !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: At the telephone .Mayfair 7521 . I promise you he shall come to no harm . Before it gets serious we ’ ll tell him that she ’ s not a Jones of Llandudno , but a Jones of Notting Hill Gate .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a giggle .I don ’ t think it ’ s quite nice what you ’ re doing .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think it ’ s horrid . I shall blame myself very much afterwards .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With your moral sense too .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hulloa , can I speak to Mr. Barlow ? Hulloa , is that you , Uncle Davenport ? No , I didn ’ t go to Paris after all .With a wink at PENELOPE .Mrs. Mack had a sudden relapse , and couldn ’ t be moved . No , Mrs. Fergusson hasn ’ t gone either .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mrs. Fergusson is in the drawing-room , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Speaking down the telephone .What ! Half a minute . Hold on .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ve been expecting her all the afternoon . Ask her if she wouldn ’ t mind coming up here .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Very well , ma ’ am .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , there ’ s no getting out of it .At the telephone .Hulloa . Why don ’ t you come round ? Mrs. Fergusson is calling on Pen , and you can arrange about your luncheon party then .... All right . Good-bye .... I say , I ’ m going to bolt .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You coward !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Pretending to be very dignified .I ’ m not a coward , Penelope . I shall be back in two minutes . But I ’ m thirsty , and I ’ m going to have a brandy and soda .

div.stage: He bends down to kiss her , but she moves away .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , hang it all , you needn ’ t grudge me one kiss .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling .Wait till you ’ re off with the old love , my friend .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think it ’ s a bit thick that a man shouldn ’ t be allowed to embrace the wife of his bosom .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You shall afterwards , if you ’ re good .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , she ’ s just coming . What a blessing this room has two doors !

div.stage: He goes out . PENELOPE gets up , looks at herself in the glass , arranges a stray lock of hair , and powders her nose . ADA FERGUSSON comes in .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Kissing her effusively .Dearest ... I hope you don ’ t mind being dragged up here .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Of course not . I like this room . I always think it ’ s just the place for a heart-to-heart talk .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How nice you ’ re looking !

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: D ’ you like my frock ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I always think it suits you so well .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Acidly .It is the first time I have put it on .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , then I suppose I ’ ve seen one just like it on other people .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You ’ ll think I ’ m coming here a great deal , dearest .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You know that Dickie and I are always glad to see you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Is Dr. O ’ Farrell at home ? I wanted to ask him something about the medicine he prescribed for me yesterday .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Now don ’ t say you ’ ve come to see Dickie . I was hoping you ’ d come to see me .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I wanted to kill two birds with one stone .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That is a feat of marksmanship which always gives one satisfaction .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I forget if you said that Dr. O ’ Farrell was at home .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You know , I think you must be the only person who ’ s known him ten minutes without calling him Dickie .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I should have no confidence in him as a doctor if I did .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I never employ him myself . I always go to Dr. Rogers .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You look as if you had robust health , dearest .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , I just manage to trip along above ground to save funeral expenses .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Is Dr. O ’ Farrell quite well ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Tired .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Wondering why .Oh ?

div.stage: A slight pause .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I suppose you haven ’ t the least idea when he ’ ll be home ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I didn ’ t know he was out .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon . I thought you said he was out .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I must have misunderstood you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I think he ’ s lying down . You see he was with poor Mrs. Mack till twelve o ’ clock last night .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With a slight start .Was he ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s so bad that she should have had a relapse when she seemed to be going on so well .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Puzzled , but trying not to show it .I was more distressed than I can say .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And it must have been so inconvenient for you after you ’ d made all your arrangements for going to Paris .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , of course , I didn ’ t think of my convenience at all .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dickie says the way you ’ ve nursed her is beyond all praise .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I think in this life we ought to do what we can for one another . I only did my duty .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: So few of us do that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: When I think of my husband bravely serving his country in a foreign land , I feel that I ought to do anything I can to help others .

div.stage: PENELOPE meditatively winks to herself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Were you there at the end ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Astounded .What end ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you don ’ t know ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Penelope , I haven ’ t an idea what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But Dickie was with Mrs. Mack all this morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: That ’ s absurd .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wonder you weren ’ t sent for .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: But ....

div.stage: She is speechless with anger and amazement .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then you really don ’ t know ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Desperately .I know nothing .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My poor , dear Ada . I ’ m distracted that I should have to give you this bitter , bitter blow . Mrs. Mack is — dead .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Dead !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: She died in Dickie ’ s arms , thanking him for all he ’ d done for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Impossible !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I don ’ t wonder you say that . She was quite frisky a day or two ago .... Sit down , dear . You ’ re quite upset . You were very fond of her , weren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Dead !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why don ’ t you have a good cry ? Can ’ t you find your handkerchief ? Take this . It ’ s very sad , isn ’ t it ? And after all you ’ d done for her ?

div.stage: MRS. FERGUSSON dabs her eyes with the handkerchief .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Forcing herself to be natural .It ’ s a great blow .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh , I know . I feel for you , dear . Dickie was devoted to her . He said he ’ d never had such a patient .Putting her handkerchief to her own eyes .She died , with a smile on her lips , mentioning her dead husband ’ s name .
