Dickie was so moved , he couldn ’ t eat any lunch , poor boy ; and we ’ re going to have a new landaulette .

div.stage: DICKIE comes in and stops at the door for a moment as he sees the two women apparently in tears .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I say , what ’ s up ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a sob .I ’ ve just broken the news to poor Ada .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What news ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: She didn ’ t know that Mrs. Mack was — no more .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Trying to conceal her rage and mystification .I certainly didn ’ t !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You ought to have let her know , Dickie . She would have liked to be — in at the death .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I wanted to spare you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It ’ s too kind of you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I knew that was it . Dickie has such a kind heart .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With restrained anger .I have already noticed it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To her husband .And you were so fond of her , weren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I looked upon her as a real friend .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ ve told Ada that she expired in your arms , darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a smile on her lips .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: That ’ s just what I said . Murmuring the name of her husband , who ’ d been dead for forty years . What did you say the name was , Dickie ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Walker , darling .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Tell Ada more . She wants to hear the details .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She asked to be remembered to you . She sent her love to your husband .

lg.l: She seems to have thought of everything . You must go to the funeral ,
Dickie .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes ; I should like to show her that sign of respect .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To MRS. FERGUSSON .Wouldn ’ t you like a glass of sherry , dearest ? I can see you ’ re quite upset .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: The — news has taken me by surprise .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: To tell you the truth , I expected it last night . But I quite understand your emotion .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ m so much obliged for your sympathy .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m going to get you some sherry myself .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , let me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: No , stay with Ada , darling . You have such a way with you when one ’ s in trouble .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Edging off .On an occasion like this a woman wants another woman with her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Preventing him from moving .No , you know just the right thing to say . I shall never forget how charming you were when our last cook gave notice .

div.stage: She goes out . MRS. FERGUSSON springs to her feet .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Now !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Good heavens ! You made me positively jump .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: What does all this mean ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It means that Mrs. Mack , like the rest of us , is mortal . The funeral takes place the day after to-morrow at Kensal Green . Friends kindly accept this the only intimation .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: How can Mrs. Mack be dead ? You know just as well as I do that she never existed .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Upon my word , I ’ m beginning to be not quite certain . I ’ ve talked about her so much that she seems much more real than — than my bank balance , for instance . And I could write a beautiful article for the Lancet on the case .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Furiously .Oh !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: After all , she did have a rotten time of it , poor old lady . Operation after operation . Life wasn ’ t worth living . She was bound to die . And I call it a jolly happy release .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Where were you last night ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I was at Mrs. Mack ’ s — no , of course , I wasn ’ t . I ’ m so used to saying that that it slips out quite naturally . I ’ m awfully sorry .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: How can you tell me such lies ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know . I suppose it ’ s growing into a habit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I recommend you to keep them for Penelope .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I suppose you think , then , they don ’ t matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , she ’ s your wife . That ’ s quite another story .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: What d ’ you mean by saying , I see ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It was the only reply I could think of at the moment .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ m sure you meant something by it .

div.stage: PEYTON comes in with a tray on which are two wine glasses and a decanter . They keep silence till she has gone out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Have a glass of sherry , will you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , I think I will if you don ’ t mind .He pours himself out a glass .I have an idea that sherry ’ s coming into fashion again .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Have you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I always think I have a knack of making myself pleasant under difficulties .

div.stage: He drinks a glass of sherry to give himself courage .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Look here , I ’ ve got something to tell you that I ’ m afraid you won ’ t very much like . I daresay you ’ ll think me an awful brute , but I ’ m bound to say it .MRS. FERGUSSON does not answer , and after a moment ’ s pause he goes on .The fact is , I ’ m not built the proper way for intrigue . All these lies make me awfully uncomfortable . I don ’ t like to think I ’ m treating Penelope badly .Another pause .I may as well tell you the whole truth bang out . I ’ ve discovered that I ’ m desperately in love with Penelope .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Calmly .And ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Rather surprised .And that ’ s all .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: And how do you imagine that interests me ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Quite embarrassed .I thought — er ....

div.stage: MRS. FERGUSSON goes into a peal of laughter . DICKIE , quite taken aback , looks at her with astonishment .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You haven ’ t been under the impression that I ever cared for you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Trying to make it out .No , no . Of course a man ’ s a conceited ass who thinks a woman ’ s in love with him .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You amused me when I first met you , but you ’ ve long ceased to do that .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It was convenient to have some one to do things for me . I ’ m a womanly woman and ....

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You don ’ t know your way about .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: For the last month you ’ ve bored me to extinction . I ’ ve done everything in my power to show you except say it right out .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I ’ ve been very dense .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Dreadfully dense .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But it was good of you to spare my feelings .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With an amiable smile .D ’ you think it would be rude if I described you in your own words as a conceited ass ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It might make our future acquaintance rather formal .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: There will be no future acquaintance .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Then there ’ s nothing more to be said .

div.stage: MRS. FERGUSSON sweeps to the door . She stops .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Does Penelope adore you as blindly as when first I met you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I venture to think she ’ s as much in love with me as I am with her .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: What have you done with the letters I wrote to you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I did as we agreed . I burnt them at once .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I didn ’ t . I kept yours .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have thought they were interesting enough .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I have an idea that Penelope would find them positively absorbing .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Why don ’ t you send them to her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: If you have no objection , I think I will .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: They will tell her nothing that she doesn ’ t know already .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Coming back , startled .You don ’ t mean to say you ’ ve told her ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She ’ s known it all along .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Known what ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Everything . From the beginning .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Terrified .How did she find out ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Heaven only knows .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It ’ s a trap ! I might have known she wasn ’ t such a fool as she seemed . She wants to divorce you , and she ’ s used me . My husband will never stand that .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I can imagine that even the most affectionate husband would draw the line there .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t try and be funny now .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I wasn ’ t . The funny part is yet to come .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Well , you needn ’ t get into a state about it . Penelope ’ s not going to do anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: But then , why ...?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .She doesn ’ t care a hang .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I don ’ t understand .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Don ’ t you ? It ’ s very simple . It ’ s a matter of no importance . She ’ s glad that I ’ ve been amused . If she only knew how much amusement I ’ ve got out of it ! She looks upon it in the light of a — of a change of air .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Furiously .Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! A fortnight ’ s golf at the seaside , I suppose .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Something like that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I ’ d sooner she divorced you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Thanks , I wouldn ’ t .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Oh , what a humiliation ! I ’ ve been just a convenience because she had other fish to fry . How sordid it makes the whole thing ! And I was yearning for romance . I would never have looked at you if I hadn ’ t thought she doted on you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I have an idea that affairs of this sort are only romantic when they happen to other people . When they happen to yourself — well , sordid ’ s just the word .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Suddenly remembering .And Mrs. Mack ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She ’ s known all about that too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: D ’ you mean that to-day when we ...?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Mingled your tears ? I think hers were about as real as yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: And she led me on to say one thing after another .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think she ’ s been pulling both our legs successfully .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: How on earth am I going to meet her now ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: She ’ ll be all right . She ’ ll be just as charming as ever .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You fool ! Don ’ t you see that if she ’ s charming to me it ’ s because she thinks she ’ s prettier than I am , and cleverer than I am , and more fascinating than I am ? She doesn ’ t even despise me , she ’ s indifferent to me .

div.stage: She goes to the glass and looks at herself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Furiously .A change of air .

div.stage: The door opens slowly , and PENELOPE comes in . She has changed into motoring things . MRS. FERGUSSON gives a sudden gasp as she sees her and turns her face away . For a moment PENELOPE stands still , looking at them reflectively . DICKIE aimlessly arranges things on a table .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a faint smile .I ’ m not disturbing you , am I ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Nothing .

div.stage: Suddenly , with a sob , MRS. FERGUSSON sinks into a chair , and hiding her face bursts into tears . PENELOPE gives her a look of surprise and goes swiftly up to her . She leans over her , with her hand on MRS. FERGUSSON ’ S shoulder .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Almost tenderly .What ? Real tears ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: In a broken voice .I feel so ridiculous .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a little smile , as if she were talking to a child .Don ’ t . Don ’ t cry .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I look such a perfect fool .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s so tiresome of our little sins to look foolish when they ’ re found out , instead of wicked .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I shall never respect myself again .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Dry your tears , dear . Uncle Davenport has just come , and he wants to know if it ’ s respectable to ask you to lunch with him alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: With a suspicion of her old manner .He ’ s so sympathetic . I ’ d like to have a heart-to-heart talk with him .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: You ’ ll find the Carlton a most suitable place .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Are my eyes red ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Not a bit . I ’ ll get you some powder .

div.stage: She takes the powder-box off a table , and MRS. FERGUSSON meditatively powders her nose .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: I like him . He talks of all the duchesses by their Christian names .

div.stage: PEYTON announces BARLOW and goes out .

sp.speaker: PEYTON
sp.p: Mr. Davenport Barlow .

div.stage: As he comes in , MRS. FERGUSSON finally and entirely regains her usual manner .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Kissing her uncle .How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Advancing gallantly to MRS. FERGUSSON .This is a pleasing surprise . I was under the impression you were in Paris .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: No , poor Mrs. Mack was suddenly taken much worse .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It is my gain .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: It ’ s too nice of you to say so , but I ’ m leaving London at once all the same .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But this is very sudden . What shall we do without you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: You must blame Dr. O ’ Farrell .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Astonished .Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: He tells me that now I ’ m quite strong enough for a foreign climate , and , of course , nothing will induce me to remain an hour away from my husband if I ’ m not obliged to .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: But I thought he was bravely fighting for his country .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Well , you see , there doesn ’ t happen to be any fighting for him to do just now , and he ’ s taken a very nice house at Malta . And I shall start to-morrow .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: This is more distressing than I can say . And are you going straight through ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: No , I shall stop a day or two in Paris on my way .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: How very singular ! I had made all arrangements to go to Paris to-morrow myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: Then would you mind looking after me on the journey ? You see , I ’ m a womanly woman , and I ’ m quite helpless in the train by myself .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: I should look upon it as a privilege . And perhaps we might go to one or two plays while you ’ re there .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: If you ’ ll promise not to take me to anything risky .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: To PENELOPE .Well , dear , I must say good-bye to you . I ’ m afraid we shan ’ t meet again for some time .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: They kiss one another affectionately .

lg.l: Good-bye . If you hear of anything good on the Stock
Exchange , you might let me know . I think I shall cut my loss on
Johannesburg and New Jerusalems .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I would .

sp.speaker: MRS. FERGUSSON
sp.p: To BARLOW .I have a cab downstairs . Can I give you a lift anywhere ?

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: It would be very kind of you .

div.stage: With a nod to DICKIE she goes out .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: Shaking hands with PENELOPE .Charming creature . So dashing and a thorough gentlewoman .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Now , mind , Uncle Davenport , no pranks .

sp.speaker: BARLOW
sp.p: My dear , I ’ m not only the soul of honour , but fifty-two .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: As he goes out .I suppose that does induce a platonic state of mind .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a sigh of relief .Ouf !PENELOPE turns to a glass to arrange her hat . DICKIE watches her with a smile .Well ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Pretending to be surprised .I beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You promised to kiss me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I didn ’ t . I promised to allow myself to be kissed .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Taking her in his arms and kissing her .You little beast .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Finished ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Not nearly .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then I ’ m afraid you must go on another time . I ’ ve got a taxi at the door , and it ’ s costing twopence a minute .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Stepping back .What d ’ you want a taxi for ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a laugh .I thought that would chill your ardour .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ re not going on that beastly motor trip now ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why on earth not ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Half injured , half surprised .Pen !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Looking at the watch on her wrist .Good gracious , I ’ m keeping them waiting .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Taking both her hands .Now don ’ t tease me . Go and take those horrid motor things off , and let ’ s have a comfortable little tea together . And tell Peyton you ’ re not at home .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m dreadfully sorry to disappoint you , but I ’ m afraid I can ’ t break an engagement .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ re not serious ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Abnormally .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: But , Pen dear , everything ’ s different now . Don ’ t you know that I love you ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: It ’ s very nice of you to say so .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Doesn ’ t it mean anything to you ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Not much .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Beginning to be rather perplexed .But , Pen dear , pull yourself together . I love you just as much as you love me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a little smile .But what makes you think I love you ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Aghast .You — you don ’ t mean to say that you don ’ t care for me any more ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Judicially .I — no longer feel that the world is coming to an end when you go out of the room .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What !... Why don ’ t you say straight out that you can ’ t bear the sight of me ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Because it wouldn ’ t be quite true . I like you very well .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Like me ! I don ’ t want you to like me . I want you to love me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wish I could . It would save a lot of bother .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t understand . This is the most extraordinary thing I ’ ve ever heard in my life . I always thought you adored me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Because I adore you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Since when ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Always , always , always .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Fancy .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , I know I made a fool of myself . I shall never cease to regret it . D ’ you think I was happy ? D ’ you think I had a jolly time ? Not much .... I suppose it ’ s that . You can ’ t forgive me ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Nonsense . Of course I forgive you . It doesn ’ t matter a bit .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: With a gesture of desperation .The whole thing ’ s Greek to me . I loved you always , Pen . I never ceased for a moment to love you .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear , you need not protest so much . It doesn ’ t very much interest me either way .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What a fool I was ! I ought to have known that if you took it so calmly it could only be because you didn ’ t care . If a woman doesn ’ t make scenes it can only mean that she doesn ’ t love you .... You used to love me ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How can you be so fickle ? I never thought you ’ d treat me like this .

div.stage: PENELOPE looks about as if she ’ d lost something .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What are you looking for ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I fancied you ’ d lost your sense of humour . I was just seeing if I could find it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: How can I have a sense of humour when I ’ m suffering ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Starting at the word .Suffering ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: The tortures of the damned . I want you . I want your love .

div.stage: He does not see PENELOPE ’ S face . An expression of remorse comes into it at the pain she is causing him . She outlines a gesture towards him , but quickly restrains herself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a mocking laugh .Poor darling .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Furiously .Don ’ t laugh at me .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I wasn ’ t . I was quite sorry for you .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: D ’ you think I want your pity ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I ’ m very unfortunate . I seem quite unable to please you . I think it ’ s just as well that I ’ m going away for a week .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Starting up .No , you ’ re not going away .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Raising her eyebrows .What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Because I forbid you to .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling .And are you under the delusion that at your command I shall fall flat on my face ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ m the master of this house , and I mean to make myself respected .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: My dear , since you pay the rent and the taxes it ’ s quite right that you should rule this house with a rod of iron if you wish it . Personally , at the moment I only want to get out of it .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: You ’ re not going out of it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Do you propose to keep me here against my will ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Certainly , if needful .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: H ’ m .

div.stage: She gets up and goes to the door . He intercepts her , locks the door , and puts the key in his pocket .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Brute force .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I think it ’ s about time I showed you I ’ m not going to be made a perfect fool of .

div.stage: PENELOPE shrugs her shoulders and sits down . Suddenly she chuckles .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t see anything to laugh at .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I do . It ’ s so mediæval . And are you going to feed me on bread and water ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Angrily .Ugh .He looks at her .Now , look here , Pen , be reasonable about it . Why the deuce d ’ you want to go for this stupid trip ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: I refuse to discuss the matter till you ’ ve opened the door .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: It ’ s not the time of year for a motor trip .Pause . PENELOPE looks straight in front of her , taking no notice of what he says .It ’ ll rain cats and dogs , and you ’ ll catch a beastly cold . You ’ ll probably get pneumonia .Pause .I ’ m feeling awfully run down , and I shouldn ’ t wonder if I were sickening for something myself .PENELOPE smothers a giggle and continues to stare into vacancy . DICKIE breaks out passionately .But don ’ t you see that if I ’ m preventing you from going , it ’ s because I can ’ t bear to let you out of my sight ? I want you . I want you always by me . I want you to love me .... Oh , if you only knew how much I love you , you wouldn ’ t be so heartless .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Turning to him and speaking quite calmly .But surely , if you cared for me , you wouldn ’ t try to deprive me of a little enjoyment . You ’ d be willing to sacrifice yourself sometimes . You ’ d have a certain regard for my wishes . You wouldn ’ t put every absurd obstacle in the way when the chance offers for me to have some amusement .

div.stage: DICKIE looks at her for a moment then turns away and walks up and down , with downcast head . He takes the key out of his pocket and silently puts it on the table beside her .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: In a broken voice .You ’ re quite right . I ’ ve simply been beastly selfish . I was only thinking of myself . I dare say I bore you . Perhaps you ’ ll like me better when you ’ ve been away for a few days .

div.stage: PENELOPE is so moved that she can hardly keep up her acting any longer . She struggles with herself , and in a moment masters the desire to throw herself in his arms .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Since you locked the door , perhaps you ’ ll be good enough to unlock it .

div.stage: Without a word he takes the key and goes to the door . He unlocks it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Am I to understand that you offer no objection to my trip ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: If it ’ ll give you pleasure to go , I shall be pleased to think you ’ re happy . I only want you to be happy .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Would you rather I stayed ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: No .

div.stage: PENELOPE gives a slight start . This is not at all what she wants .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know what I shall do without you . I feel as if I were only now getting to know you . It ’ s as though — oh , I don ’ t know how to express it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: But you ’ ve just said you would rather I went .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I don ’ t want to think of myself any more . I want to think only of you . It makes me so happy to think of you , Pen . I want to sacrifice myself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Relieved .Will you go to my room and see if my bag has been taken down ?

div.stage: He goes out for a moment . She remains with an ecstatic look on her face . He comes back .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Yes . Peyton ’ s taken it .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Then —she gives him a look from beneath her eye-lashes— ring and tell her to bring it up again .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hardly able to believe his good fortune .Pen !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Are you pleased ?

lg.l: Oh , you ’ re much too good to me . I can ’ t tell you how grateful I am . Oh ,
Pen , if you only knew how much I adore you !

div.stage: He falls on his knees and passionately kisses her hands . She can hardly restrain herself from lifting him up and flinging her arms round his neck .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Is there any chance for me at all ? D ’ you think you ’ ll ever love me as you used to ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: How can I tell ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , why can ’ t we go back to the beginning ? D ’ you remember how we loved one another then ? You used to come down with me every day when I went out , and when I came back you always ran down to kiss me . And d ’ you remember how you used to sit on my chair in the morning while I smoked my pipe and we read the paper together ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Concealing a smile .How you must have hated it !

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Hate it ? I ’ ve never been so happy in my life .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: At all events I hope we shall always continue to be good friends .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Starting up .Friends ! What ’ s the good of offering me your friendship when I ’ m starving for your love ? How can you make me so unhappy ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Smiling indulgently .But I ’ m not going to make you unhappy . I hope I shall always be very pleasant and agreeable .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: What d ’ you think I care for that ? Pen , promise that you ’ ll try to love me ?

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: With a smile .Yes , I ’ ll try if you like .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I ’ ll make you love me . I ’ ll never rest till I ’ m sure of your love .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: And when you are sure of it I suppose you won ’ t care twopence for me any more ?

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Try me ! Try me !

div.stage: He kisses her hands again . He does not see her face . She smiles and shakes her head .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: I never knew that you were so adorable . It fills me with rapture merely to kiss your hands .

div.stage: PENELOPE gives a little laugh and releases herself .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Now I must just go to the Hendersons and tell them I can ’ t come motoring .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Can ’ t you telephone ? I don ’ t want to let you out of my sight .

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: They ’ re not on the telephone . It ’ ll be more convenient for me to go .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Very well . If you must , I suppose you must .

div.stage: She smiles and goes to the door . When she reaches it he stops her .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: Oh , Pen !

sp.speaker: PENELOPE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DICKIE
sp.p: At what time will you be back ?

div.stage: Recognising the phrase , she gives a gesture of amusement , quickly kisses her hand to him , and slips out of the door .
